subject: Avoid empty values in 'mounts' options
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-02-10 19:33:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-zunclient/commit/0c6e3d9fab3c9c94c48c8ce80c42d0c5a0fba11c', 'message': "[WIP] Avoid empty values in 'mounts' options

Change-Id: Ic073098c8cd30bbf7e477c22bbdc59cb6f6bd18f
Closes-Bug: #1747282
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-02-10 20:18:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-zunclient/commit/51f2a088e74543ae2b7e3cdfcc22f8a0565ca0bb', 'message': "Avoid empty values in 'mounts' options

The python-zunclient sends the 'mounts' parameter to server
in one of the following forms:
1. {'source': xxx, 'destination': xxx, 'size': ''}
2. {'size': xxx, 'destination': xxx, 'source': ''}

This patch changes it to:
1. {'source': xxx, 'destination': xxx}
2. {'size': xxx, 'destination': xxx}

The new form doesn't contain a key with empty string value.
This allows a better validation on the server side in the
future.

Change-Id: Ic073098c8cd30bbf7e477c22bbdc59cb6f6bd18f
Closes-Bug: #1747282
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2018-03-05 03:32:35.000000000', 'files': ['zunclient/common/utils.py', 'zunclient/tests/unit/v1/test_containers_shell.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-zunclient/commit/e911859388d5a6b05dbd0857a70b225ba219b732', 'message': "Avoid empty values in 'mounts' options

The python-zunclient sends the 'mounts' parameter to server
in one of the following forms:
1. {'source': xxx, 'destination': xxx, 'size': ''}
2. {'size': xxx, 'destination': xxx, 'source': ''}

This patch changes it to:
1. {'source': xxx, 'destination': xxx}
2. {'size': xxx, 'destination': xxx}

The new form doesn't contain a key with empty string value.
This allows a better validation on the server side in the
future.

Change-Id: Ic073098c8cd30bbf7e477c22bbdc59cb6f6bd18f
Closes-Bug: #1747282
"}]
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zunclient refs/changes/36/543136/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: keys = ["source", "destination", "size"] mount_info = {} if k in keys: if mount_info.get(k): if not mount_info.get('destination'): if not mount_info.get('source') and not mount_info.get('size'):
deleted_lines: mount_info = {"source": "", "destination": "", "size": ""} if k in mount_info: if mount_info[k]: if not mount_info['destination']: if not mount_info['source'] and not mount_info['size']:

commit_message:
Fix conflicted Request class name

This patch changes the class and module name
from swift.common.middleware.s3api.request.Request
to swift.common.middleware.s3api.s3request.S3Request

And then, fix some broken issues related to the module name and path
change.

Change-Id: I00adc53e2f0f01b712c57b4572ed3ec51877fe49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/75/556775/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add assertions for container arguments

Change-Id: Ia2ea5ed66c4ecd30bcbf10b991bd1160daca56e6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zunclient refs/changes/37/543137/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _get_container_args(**kwargs): default_args = { 'auto_remove': False, 'environment': {}, 'hints': {}, 'labels': {}, 'mounts': [], 'nets': [], } default_args.update(kwargs) return default_args mock_create.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', image_pull_policy='never')) mock_create.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', image_pull_policy='always')) mock_create.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', image_pull_policy='ifnotpresent')) mock_create.assert_called_with(**_get_container_args(image='x')) mock_create.assert_not_called() mock_run.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', image_pull_policy='never')) mock_run.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', image_pull_policy='always')) mock_run.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', image_pull_policy='ifnotpresent')) mock_run.assert_called_with(**_get_container_args(image='x')) mock_run.assert_not_called() mock_run.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', runtime='runc')) mounts = [{'source': 's', 'destination': 'd', 'size': ''}] mock_run.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', mounts=mounts)) mock_run.assert_called_with( **_get_container_args(image='x', hostname='testhost'))

commit_message:
Neutron: Move all config to be directly values driven.

This PS moves all the config files to be directly values driven,
both simplifying over-ride and allowing configs to be targeted
to pods in future work.

Change-Id: Ifcbc19b17aa1d145f12ed1aed8b15a69ca045bb7

commit_message:
Remove duplicate configuration options on trove templates

The option neutron_endpoint_type is duplicate on these files:
 - trove/templates/trove.conf.j2
 - trove/templates/trove-taskmanager.conf.j2

We just have to remove one occurrence.

Change-Id: If5c91cf7b491966b1deac42c694af5995df9b11e

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ironic refs/changes/12/556712/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # DEPRECATED PARAMETERS # # [*revocation_cache_time*] # (Optional) Determines the frequency at which the list of revoked tokens is # retrieved from the Identity service (in seconds). A high number of # revocation events combined with a low cache duration may significantly # reduce performance. Only valid for PKI tokens. Integer value # Defaults to undef # # DEPRECATED PARAMETERS $revocation_cache_time = undef, if $revocation_cache_time { warning('revocation_cache_time parameter is deprecated, has no effect and will be removed in the future.') }

commit_message:
Add ff-upg to featureset table

This is being submitted as a separate patch so that we don't risk the
actual important FFU patch colliding with any other featureset table
change. This table-only patch is small and should be easy to rebase
and we don't mind delaying it a bit due to conflicts.

Change-Id: Iab0bdc8472a0f83a262b6e7cc1a7e2b31d517c6a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/72/555372/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Refactor setting default CA

This merely breaks the code that sets the default CA in the deployment
workflow to more functions. Preparing for setting the certificate for
the overcloud in a subsequent commit.

Change-Id: I8076604be59878703976380123532e06832ca918
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/35/554835/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cacert_string = self._get_local_cacert(local_ca_path) if cacert_string: parameters['CAMap'] = self._get_updated_camap_entry( 'undercloud-ca', cacert_string, self._get_camap(env)) def _get_local_cacert(self, local_ca_path): return ca_file.read() return None except Exception: raise def _get_camap(self, env): return env['parameter_defaults'].get('CAMap', {}) def _get_updated_camap_entry(self, entry_name, cacert, orig_camap): ca_map_entry = { entry_name: { 'content': cacert } } orig_camap.update(ca_map_entry) return orig_camap
deleted_lines: cacert = ca_file.read() ca_map_entry = { 'undercloud-ca': { 'content': cacert } } parameters['CAMap'] = env['parameter_defaults'].get('CAMap', {}) parameters['CAMap'].update(ca_map_entry) pass

commit_message:
Create base server listening on sbus

This patch introduces basic implementation of the server processes
to execute operations corresponding to the request on sbus
procotol, which is a common base for agents running in docker
container.

NOTE:
This patch also fixes broken unit tests about storlet_daemon

Change-Id: I4c45861e6946a518afa6cf0f96e99e3d177259d9

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I9ea7e69986056f1172e834e01d9e3dcbcaa3a22b
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Install horizon from git

Install horizon in OpenStack CI from git instead of using tarball, this
allows depends-on to work.

Update tox.ini and requirements.txt for proper setup.

subject: Fix missing parentid on rule delete journal record
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-26 22:19:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/commit/0f091c81033240592df2416094b060ce4efa1cb1', 'message': 'Fix missing parentid on rule delete journal record

This fixes an error raised when deleting a security group if there are
pending rules to be deleted of that group as records in the journal
that were not triggered by the group deletion operation itself so that
they did not have the parent security group id as data of the record.

This happens when the rule and the group are deleted independently but
in rapid succession. It does not happen when the rules are deleted as a
consequence of deleting the group since the parentid is correctly set
in that case, neither when the group is deleted some time after the
rules when their records might have already been processed and removed.

This problem was encountered in OPNFV functest environment but may also
fix https://jira.opendaylight.org/browse/NETVIRT-896 and complement
change #533706.

Change-Id: I5ccdbdea9d803334c8ae9416b40e3c4b48a8144b
Closes-Bug: 1744966
Signed-off-by: Jaime Caamao Ruiz <jcaamano@suse.com>

commit_message:
Fix missing parentid on rule delete journal record

This fixes an error raised when deleting a security group if there are
pending rules to be deleted of that group as records in the journal
that were not triggered by the group deletion operation itself so that
they did not have the parent security group id as data of the record.

This happens when the rule and the group are deleted independently but
in rapid succession. It does not happen when the rules are deleted as a
consequence of deleting the group since the parentid is correctly set
in that case, neither when the group is deleted some time after the
rules when their records might have already been processed and removed.

This problem was encountered in OPNFV functest environment but may also
fix [1] and complement [2].

[1] https://jira.opendaylight.org/browse/NETVIRT-896
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/536935

Change-Id: I5ccdbdea9d803334c8ae9416b40e3c4b48a8144b
Closes-Bug: 1744966
Signed-off-by: Jaime Caamao Ruiz <jcaamano@suse.com>
(cherry picked from commit 2c15a7926dfd24ee363a15c53ac44dedfae7e0ce)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl refs/changes/52/538352/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: data = resource_dict if (operation == odl_const.ODL_DELETE): # NOTE(yamahata): DB auto deletion # Security Group Rule under this Security Group needs to # be deleted. At NeutronDB layer rules are auto deleted with # cascade='all,delete'. if (object_type == odl_const.ODL_SG): for rule_id in kwargs['security_group_rule_ids']: journal.record(context, odl_const.ODL_SG_RULE, rule_id, odl_const.ODL_DELETE, [object_uuid]) elif (object_type == odl_const.ODL_SG_RULE): # Set the parent security group id so that dependencies # to this security rule deletion can be properly found # in the journal. data = [kwargs['security_group_id']] operation, data)
deleted_lines: # NOTE(yamahata): DB auto deletion # Security Group Rule under this Security Group needs to # be deleted. At NeutronDB layer rules are auto deleted with # cascade='all,delete'. if (object_type == odl_const.ODL_SG and operation == odl_const.ODL_DELETE): for rule_id in kwargs['security_group_rule_ids']: journal.record(context, odl_const.ODL_SG_RULE, rule_id, odl_const.ODL_DELETE, [object_uuid]) operation, resource_dict)

commit_message:
Update default ETCD_VERSION to latest 3.2 etcd release

This updates the default ETCD_VERSION to the latest 3.2 etcd release,
v3.2.17.  3.2 is chosen as it is packaged in bionic and fedora; we
hope to move to packaged versions for distros that support it in due
course.

This version supports arm64 and ppc64le which were not supported by the
previous default, v3.1.10.

We have removed the override to tarballs.o.o, as these files are now
cached as described in [1]

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-infra/2018-March/005871.html

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/556688
Change-Id: I5103b4331a8d7c5660848fc148ebe4139ce6dad9

commit_message:
Don't raise when delete non-existent image in docker

When delete an image, we check whether 404 is in the exception.
If the image doesn't exist in docker, we can continue to delete
the image in DB.

Change-Id: Ic500fbec9159059d89fde879bc4b0aa7389e8abe

commit_message:
generate latest sample config file along with document

Currently, when users want to get the sample config file, they
need to install many development tools such as git, tox and etc,
then run `tox -egenconfig` to get it.

oslo_config provides a tool named sphinxconfiggen since version
2.3.0, which enables us generate the sample config file along with
document.

Let's use it, so users can directly download it from our document
site.

Change-Id: Ic2eedfcd26b43ef77b042ac986be61274276063b

This patch adds the command output text to the error logging when we use
subprocess.check_output().

commit_message:
Refactor the ceilometer transformer

Change-Id: Ic22adf816db622483c3feae903185f35e050f3aa

added_lines: def generic_strip(self, datatype, data, id_key=None): res_data = super(CeilometerTransformer, self).generic_strip(datatype, data) if id_key: res_data[id_key] = data.resource_id return res_data def _strip_compute(self, data): res_data = self.generic_strip('compute', data, 'instance_id') return self.generic_strip('volume', data) return self.generic_strip('image', data, 'image_id') return self.generic_strip('network_tap', data, 'interface_id') return self.generic_strip('network_floating', data, 'floatingip_id')
deleted_lines: def _strip_compute(self, data): res_data = self.generic_strip('compute', data) res_data['instance_id'] = data.resource_id res_data = self.generic_strip('volume', data) res_data['user_id'] = data.user_id res_data['project_id'] = data.project_id return res_data res_data = self.generic_strip('image', data) res_data['image_id'] = data.resource_id res_data['project_id'] = data.project_id res_data['user_id'] = data.user_id return res_data res_data = self.generic_strip('network_tap', data) res_data['user_id'] = data.user_id res_data['project_id'] = data.project_id res_data['interface_id'] = data.resource_id return res_data res_data = self.generic_strip('network_floating', data) res_data['user_id'] = data.user_id res_data['project_id'] = data.project_id res_data['floatingip_id'] = data.resource_id return res_data

commit_message:
Reduce runtime for l7rule too_many_rules test

Running 50 times (our max limit for l7 rules) takes a really long time.
If we mock the limit to something more reasonable, it will still
validate that we limit correctly.

Change-Id: Id95c84f2a6f552714f1af955cf027e7f50d90ab0

commit_message:
Remove cinder v1 service and endpoints

The cinder v1 API was removed in the queens release. The
'os_keystone_service' module is used to allow removal of existing
services and endpoints. Disabling the v2 API will now also ensure there
is not a registered service or endpoints.

The 'cinder_enable_v3_api' variable has been removed since it had no
effect on cinder's enablement of the v3 API.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/557016/
Change-Id: I02d2bae8712c0ca223cafb5a43304806c4b83125

commit_message:
ansible-role-requirements: Use systemd_service role from git.o.o

In order to ensure that the updated role is used for tests,
we adjust the a-r-r file to pull from the correct repo.

commit_message:
Fix neutron with extensions job

* Extend neutron-with-extensions job with a proper required_projects
  section. It allows to launch all neutron extensions which we have
  in legacy job (except openstack/neutron-fwaas which has
  broken/uncompatible devstack plugin)
* Move load-balancing checks to the separate job

commit_message:
add a validation rule to prevent pre-releases after finals

Add a validation rule to prevent someone from tagging a release using
a pre-release version (alpha, beta, rc) in a series after a final has
been tagged for that series.

Change-Id: Ia0c84d37bec43725d93b0c7daea0a68bace6407d
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

PTL Elections -------------

commit_message:
rearrange requirements check code to add tests

Rearrange and refactor the existing requirements check logic to better
support testing.  Add a few tests for the function that determines if
a setting matches the global requirements.

Change-Id: I3ea9049cf728b11ef71ca180304ee7041303a409
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/32/557032/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (C) 2011 OpenStack, LLC. # Copyright (c) 2013 Hewlett-Packard Development Company, L.P. # Copyright (c) 2013 OpenStack Foundation # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections from openstack_requirements import project from openstack_requirements import requirement class RequirementsList(object): def __init__(self, name, project): self.name = name self.reqs_by_file = {} self.project = project self.failed = False @property def reqs(self): return {k: v for d in self.reqs_by_file.values() for k, v in d.items()} def extract_reqs(self, content, strict): reqs = collections.defaultdict(set) parsed = requirement.parse(content) for name, entries in parsed.items(): if not name: # Comments and other unprocessed lines continue list_reqs = [r for (r, line) in entries] # Strip the comments out before checking if there are duplicates list_reqs_stripped = [r._replace(comment='') for r in list_reqs] if strict and len(list_reqs_stripped) != len(set( list_reqs_stripped)): print("Requirements file has duplicate entries " "for package %s : %r." % (name, list_reqs)) self.failed = True reqs[name].update(list_reqs) return reqs def process(self, strict=True): """Convert the project into ready to use data. - an iterable of requirement sets to check - each set has the following rules: - each has a list of Requirements objects - duplicates are not permitted within that list """ print("Checking %(name)s" % {'name': self.name}) # First, parse. for fname, content in self.project.get('requirements', {}).items(): print("Processing %(fname)s" % {'fname': fname}) if strict and not content.endswith('\n'): print("Requirements file %s does not " "end with a newline." % fname) self.reqs_by_file[fname] = self.extract_reqs(content, strict) for name, content in project.extras(self.project).items(): print("Processing .[%(extra)s]" % {'extra': name}) self.reqs_by_file[name] = self.extract_reqs(content, strict) def _is_requirement_in_global_reqs(req, global_reqs): # Compare all fields except the extras field as the global # requirements should not have any lines with the extras syntax # example: oslo.db[xyz]<1.2.3 for req2 in global_reqs: if (req.package == req2.package and req.location == req2.location and req.specifiers == req2.specifiers and req.markers == req2.markers and req.comment == req2.comment): return True return False def get_global_reqs(content): """Return global_reqs structure. Parse content and return dict mapping names to sets of Requirement objects." """ global_reqs = {} parsed = requirement.parse(content) for k, entries in parsed.items(): # Discard the lines: we don't need them. global_reqs[k] = set(r for (r, line) in entries) return global_reqs def validate(head_reqs, branch_reqs, blacklist, global_reqs): failed = False # iterate through the changing entries and see if they match the global # equivalents we want enforced for fname, freqs in head_reqs.reqs_by_file.items(): print("Validating %(fname)s" % {'fname': fname}) for name, reqs in freqs.items(): counts = {} if (name in branch_reqs.reqs and reqs == branch_reqs.reqs[name]): # Unchanged [or a change that preserves a current value] continue if name in blacklist: # Blacklisted items are not synced and are managed # by project teams as they see fit, so no further # testing is needed. continue if name not in global_reqs: failed = True print("Requirement %s not in openstack/requirements" % str(reqs)) continue if reqs == global_reqs[name]: continue for req in reqs: if req.extras: for extra in req.extras: counts[extra] = counts.get(extra, 0) + 1 else: counts[''] = counts.get('', 0) + 1 if not _is_requirement_in_global_reqs( req, global_reqs[name]): failed = True print("Requirement for package %s : %s does " "not match openstack/requirements value : %s" % ( name, str(req), str(global_reqs[name]))) for extra, count in counts.items(): if count != len(global_reqs[name]): failed = True print("Package %s%s requirement does not match " "number of lines (%d) in " "openstack/requirements" % ( name, ('[%s]' % extra) if extra else '', len(global_reqs[name]))) return failed

commit_message:
Remove required-projects from job definition

Given that the parent is the functional job, which already
includes all the required roles, this is unnecessary and
only serves to slow down the test.

Change-Id: Iadcebc9eca9e279ea647a7a35bff5d00f82489f1
(cherry picked from commit 1416166a705f4f3eed9547aa86a899a777aec134)

commit_message:
Remove required-projects from job definition

Given that the parent is the functional job, which already
includes all the required roles, this is unnecessary and
only serves to slow down the test.

Change-Id: Iadcebc9eca9e279ea647a7a35bff5d00f82489f1
(cherry picked from commit 1416166a705f4f3eed9547aa86a899a777aec134)

commit_message:
Reduce stestr concurrency to 1 for tempest jobs

The switch from testr to stestr introduced in Change-Id
Icf1f9eb4539666dffb6c9c1651670541523a9f9e missed setting concurrency
jobs to 1 for api and scenario tests, leading to intermittent gate
issues.

This patch also fixes coverage test that got broken in the
aforementioned Change-Id.

Change-Id: I052a9c3b376624f8e9e63faa98f4d09a93bdde4d
(cherry picked from commit f27c44c478ba5602f91eea0aa37b5fea8b941015)

commit_message:
Ensure doc8 is run

When a doc8 issue has been detected, the CI job must fail.

Change-Id: Ic4a5867b5c38643231f5af97acb4d66878a2ae4d

commit_message:
DNM: tentative hack to point to neutron-lib master

This is a hack to allow testing changes stacked on this one
with neutron-lib change Id5aea04553b78dd17fca85de88cf076b42d24140.

The Depends-On magic does not work when neutron-lib is not
declared in zuul job 'required-projects' attribute.

Change-Id: Icec21d35ba2bfe00737380a543bd50fa72a8dd5c

subject: Fix hypervisor_type in /os-hypervisors/details
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-05 07:37:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a9c1d630768ee45adb408c5e3f76e5feee9eded7', 'message': "Use virt_type in /os-hypervisors/details API

Microversion 2.59 responses virt_type instead of hypervisor_type in
GET /os-hypervisors/details API if hypervisor_type is 'QEMU'.

If libvirt virt_type is kvm or qemu, ComputeNode.hypervisor_type is
'QEMU', no matter whether KVM or QEMU is used for libvirt backend.
This is because both KVM and QEMU guests are serviced by the driver
for the qemu:// URI in libvirt.

For this reason, this patch changes /os-hypervisors/details API to
return virt_type, which is passed by operator to each compute node
via nova.conf if hypervisor_type is QEMU.

Closes-Bug: #1195361
Change-Id: Iad94cfb499f972d51c2ab1d00d91ec32249f1cee
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-01-05 09:50:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/0975123fc89cc5ca66e464cbf0b4659eccb7a5db', 'message': "Fix hypervisor_type in /os-hypervisors/details

In GET /os-hypervisors/details API, microversion 2.59 makes a response
for hypervisor_type value from ComputeNode.supported_hv_specs object
instead of retrieving it from ComputeNode.hypervisor_type in GET
/os-hypervisors/details API if the actual backend is KVM or QEMU.

If libvirt virt_type is kvm or qemu, ComputeNode.hypervisor_type is
'QEMU', no matter whether KVM or QEMU is used for the actual backend.
This is because both KVM and QEMU guests are serviced by the driver
for the qemu:// URI in libvirt and libvirt's getType() API, via which
Nova gets the value, returns QEMU in both cases.

We are not going to change this value directly because this is used
for version checking in nova's libvirt driver, and that, actually,
it is hypervisor_type from supported_hv_specs, which we are now using
in scheduler filters such as ImagePropertiesFilter, and that really
matters for operators and end-users.

For this reason, this patch changes /os-hypervisors/details API to
retrieve the hypervisor_type value from supported_hv_specs, which
is guaranteed to have the same value with virt_type, if
Computenode.hypervisor_type returns 'QEMU' value.

Closes-Bug: #1195361
Change-Id: Iad94cfb499f972d51c2ab1d00d91ec32249f1cee

commit_message:
Fix hypervisor_type in /os-hypervisors/details

In GET /os-hypervisors/details API, microversion 2.61 makes a response
for hypervisor_type value from ComputeNode.supported_hv_specs object
instead of retrieving it from ComputeNode.hypervisor_type in GET
/os-hypervisors/details API if the actual backend is KVM or QEMU.

If libvirt virt_type is kvm or qemu, ComputeNode.hypervisor_type is
'QEMU', no matter whether KVM or QEMU is used for the actual backend.
This is because both KVM and QEMU guests are serviced by the driver
for the qemu:// URI in libvirt and libvirt's getType() API, via which
Nova gets the value, returns QEMU in both cases.

We are not going to change this value directly because this is used
for version checking in nova's libvirt driver, and that, actually,
it is hypervisor_type from supported_hv_specs, which we are now using
in scheduler filters such as ImagePropertiesFilter, and that really
matters for operators and end-users.

For this reason, this patch changes /os-hypervisors/details API to
retrieve the hypervisor_type value from supported_hv_specs, which
is guaranteed to have the same value with virt_type, if
Computenode.hypervisor_type returns 'QEMU' value.

Closes-Bug: #1195361
Blueprint: support-kvm-hypervisor-api
Change-Id: Iad94cfb499f972d51c2ab1d00d91ec32249f1cee

If libvirt's `virt_type` is set to `kvm` or `qemu`,
`GET /os-hypervisors/details` returns `QEMU` for the
`hypervisor_type` regardless of whether the backend is
KVM accelerated or not.

This spec changes it to return `KVM` if KVM acceleration

commit_message:
Report KVM hypervisor_type in hypervisor API

If libvirt's `virt_type` is set to `kvm` or `qemu`,
`GET /os-hypervisors/details` returns `QEMU` for the
`hypervisor_type` regardless of whether the backend is
KVM accelerated or not.

This spec changes it to return `KVM` if KVM acceleration
is used on that host.

Change-Id: I308ac36f12c9d7de673073b57d1a4e3eb4829e87
Blueprint: support-kvm-hypervisor-api
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/75/554075/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================ Report KVM hypervisor_type in hypervisor API ============================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/support-kvm-hypervisor-api If libvirt's ``virt_type`` is set to ``kvm`` or ``qemu``, ``GET /os-hypervisors/details`` returns ``QEMU`` for the ``hypervisor_type`` regardless of whether the backend is KVM accelerated or not. This spec changes it to return ``KVM`` if KVM acceleration is used. Problem description =================== As described in `OpenStack Architecture Design Guide`_, QEMU and KVM are defined as different hypervisors in OpenStack. .. _`OpenStack Architecture Design Guide`: https://docs.openstack.org/arch-design/design-compute/design-compute-hypervisor.html When the hypervisor is ``QEMU`` in nova, the instances on that hosts are not accelerated by hardware and the QEMU will use the `Tiny Code Generator (TCG)`_. QEMU will emulate completely CPU processors as a standalone software. It works by a special recompiler that transforms binary code written for a given processor into another one. In other words, QEMU TCG is focused on hardware emulation and portability. .. _`Tiny Code Generator (TCG)`: https://wiki.qemu.org/Documentation/TCG When the hypervisor is ``KVM`` in nova, the instances on that hosts are accelerated by hardware virtualization technology such as Intel-VT and AMD-V. QEMU will use `KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine)`_, which is Linux kernel module that allows a user space program access to the hardware virtualization technology. .. _`KVM (Kernel-based Virtual Machine)`: https://wiki.qemu.org/Features/KVM ``QEMU`` has worse performance than ``KVM`` and is a poor choice for a production deployment. The typical uses cases for ``QEMU`` are * Running on older hardware that lacks virtualization support. * Running the Compute service inside of a virtual machine for development or testing purposes, where the hypervisor does not support native virtualization for guests. As described above, ``KVM`` and ``QEMU`` are different backends. However, operators have no way to distinguish them. This is because ``GET /os-hypervisors/details`` returns ``QEMU`` for the ``hypervisor_type`` regardless of whether the backend is KVM accelerated or not. Use Cases --------- As an operator, I'd like to know if KVM is accelerated or not on a specific host from the hypervisor API. Proposed change =============== Change ``GET /os-hypervisors/details`` to return ``KVM`` for the ``hypervisor_type`` if KVM acceleration is available on that host. Alternatives ------------ One alternative is to fix this as a bug. But we bring this feature with microversion. This is because the current API response is right to some extent. Strictly speaking, KVM is technically not a hypervior and requires QEMU ontop to work. Data model impact ----------------- N/A REST API impact --------------- Change ``GET /os-hypervisors/details`` to return ``KVM`` instead of ``QEMU`` for the ``hypervisor_type`` if KVM acceleration is used. Security impact --------------- N/A Notifications impact -------------------- N/A Other end user impact --------------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ N/A Other deployer impact --------------------- N/A Developer impact ---------------- N/A Upgrade impact -------------- N/A Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tetsuro0907 Work Items ---------- * Change ``GET /os-hypervisors/details`` to return ``KVM`` instead of ``QEMU`` for the ``hypervisor_type`` if KVM acceleration is used with a new microversion. * Update python-novaclient to use that microversion. Dependencies ============ N/A Testing ======= Need functional tests for the new path. Documentation Impact ==================== Need release note to describe the fix. References ========== The current behavior is reported in the `launchpad`_. .. _launchpad: https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1195361

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ib03b8b7870ff810d60d848e09989448fb539ab99
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
XenAPI: use dom0's hostname for nova-compute

When the virt dirver is xenapi, we should explicitly specify host
with dom0's hostname for nova-compute. The host field should be same
as neutron-openvswitch-agent-xenapi.

In order to use dom0's hostname, we need pull the bootstrap_xenapi
to before running nova config tasks. The dom0's hostname will be
included in the XenAPI facts.

Change-Id: Ibfc964bbd6c569062ad33c1399f9a4612baf5b92
blueprint: xenserver-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/90/554190/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update RDO install guide for v3

Bring the RDO install guide into alignment with the Ubuntu and SUSE
guides by removing references to the admin port 35357 that was used for
the keystone v2 API.

Change-Id: Ic2c5452dae0c142ce3311f6b5e6d9590d618fc22
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/23/556023/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: Before the Queens release, keystone needed to be run on two separate ports to accomodate the Identity v2 API which ran a separate admin-only service commonly on port 35357. With the removal of the v2 API, keystone can be run on the same port for all interfaces. --bootstrap-admin-url http://controller:5000/v3/ \
deleted_lines: .. note:: This guide uses the Apache HTTP server with ``mod_wsgi`` to serve Identity service requests on ports 5000 and 35357. By default, the keystone service still listens on these ports. Therefore, this guide manually disables the keystone service. --bootstrap-admin-url http://controller:35357/v3/ \

commit_message:
Remove admin interface in sample Apache file

We provide a sample Apache file for mod_wsgi that references the admin
port 35357. This is consumed by distributors such as RDO[1]. To bring
consumers of this example file in line with the other distributors,
this patch removes the vhost for the admin port from the example.

[1] https://review.rdoproject.org/r/gitweb?p=openstack/keystone-distgit.git;a=blob;f=openstack-keystone.spec;h=b59c2a7c1ca546d205dafe278e035da5ee829728;hb=refs/heads/queens-rdo#l209

Change-Id: I86b5a43beb18e730c2b18a36316d51751e6c1696

commit_message:
project: Split quota update into a separate workflow

This commit converts the quota update workflow tab into
a separate workflow. After this change, admin cannot set
a project's quotas in the project creation workflow,
but the admin can update its quotas just after creating a project,
so I think it is not a problem.

Because of splitting quota update from a project create/update workflow,
our unit tests has been simplified significantly. Previously we needed
tests for **combination** of create/update project and quota update,
but we now need only tests for create/update project and quota update
separately.

Part of blueprint horizon-plugin-tab-for-info-and-quotas
Change-Id: I7b95428e89ddc1c7a85a1162db29cef9a9674129

commit_message:
Use redis as gnocchi incoming storage and tooz backend when enabled

- redis is much faster than ceph as incoming storage
- redis tooz backend is full implemented

Change-Id: Ia0b4bc65ea11e504c82fc8a5ad8aa447bee00630

commit_message:
Add cpu_mode into deployment-philosophy.rst

With libvirt 2.0, when using qemu cpu mode is not properly
evaluated and need to be set to cpu_mode = none.

Add this option when kvm is not supported, otherwise user
will still facing errors when launching instances over qemu.

Change-Id: I1e25fc5429b92f77ce87f537467f97b510fa154a

commit_message:
Switch to tempest run cli for running tempest tests

* https://review.openstack.org/504345 moves the tempest run cli
  from ostestr/testr to stestr.
* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/547105/ fixes the issue of
  running blacklist and whitelist tests together.

Change-Id: I51cabe762413748ac8d28bca55c15e4ea5c20dc5

commit_message:
Update run_tests.sh and remove tests-repo-clone.sh

The lint tests make use of the common linters test
used by the roles, so we need to ensure that the
run_tests.sh script is updated and the configuration
adjusted accordingly.

Change-Id: I1a5f97b770f1931a40af334f3a87766f02e572d7

commit_message:
Remove 'executable' arg from command task

Eliminates the following warning:

[WARNING]: As of Ansible 2.4, the parameter 'executable' is no longer
supported with the 'command' module. Not using '/bin/bash'.

Change-Id: Ie540ad28eec47b615ed6e1a36b25959eb6cd21c2
Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>

subject: [Urgent] correct remap logic
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-02-01 16:03:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tricircleclient/commit/96996c2572b2205312d3a1d76673c45a98bb9ed3', 'message': '[Urgent] correct remap logic

The previous implementation uses "replace" to map the
model field to display column, which will incorrectly
map "project id" to "project ID" since (id -> ID) is
also in the mapping. This patch changes to use exact
match of string so "project id" can be correctly map
to "Project".

Change-Id: I29980a834bc74fea74399c3ee15a25942e771016
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-02-02 01:39:22.000000000', 'files': ['tricircleclient/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tricircleclient/commit/5f3f6628a01fbdace3da65c46f32f1685e36edfa', 'message': '[Urgent] correct remap logic

The previous implementation uses "replace" to map the
model field to display column, which will incorrectly
map "project id" to "project ID" since (id -> ID) is
also in the mapping. This patch sorts the mapping by
the length of key to do a longest match so "project id"
will be replaced as "Project" first.

Change-Id: I29980a834bc74fea74399c3ee15a25942e771016
'}]
commit_message:
[Urgent] correct remap logic

The previous implementation uses "replace" to map the
model field to display column, which will incorrectly
map "project id" to "project ID" since (id -> ID) is
also in the mapping. This patch sorts the mapping by
the length of key to do a longest match so "project id"
will be replaced as "Project" first.

Change-Id: I29980a834bc74fea74399c3ee15a25942e771016
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tricircleclient refs/changes/98/539998/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if c in remap: c = remap[c]
deleted_lines: for old, new in remap.items(): c = c.replace(old, new)

commit_message:
Use assertEqual() instead of assertDictEqual()

Use assertEqual() instead of assertDictEqual()
In unittest2, assertDictEqual() is implemented
by using != operator to compare two dicts.
So is assertEqual() in testtools.
assertEqual() in testtools is able to handle
dict, list, set and so on. So we just call
assertEqual() to make the unit tests simpler.

Change-Id: I5035de8cc922e20a623b0aafdfba7da3263db0a6

commit_message:
Error path of WSGIScriptAlias of panko for ubuntu

Error path[1] of WSGIScriptAlias of panko for ubuntu, the right path is
/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/panko/api/app.wsgi.

[1]http://logs.openstack.org/02/504302/4/check/puppet-openstack-beaker-xenial/aeb24d6/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-02-28_00_39_06_878490

Change-Id: I15099dcfeac3c4ebaf5bd9e93188d60bbd1469df
Closes-Bug: #1753865

commit_message:
Add option to specify the timeout for reproducer script

Current default timeout for jobs running in CI is 180
minutes which is not sufficient for some of the scenarios
to complete. This patch set's default timeout for reproducer
script to 240 minutes which should be sufficient for most
of the scenarios and add an option -t|--timeout to override
this default.

Change-Id: Iad864e2edb03d66b09d612178c2fbec0d4501fc1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/51/555251/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: : ${TIMEOUT:=240} echo " -t, --timeout" echo " Timeout in minutes for the deployment" echo " Default is 240 minutes" shift ;; --timeout|-t) TIMEOUT=$2export REMAINING_TIME="$TIMEOUT"

commit_message:
Stable keepalived priorities

The calculation of the keepalived priority depended on the set of hosts
in the ansible_play_hosts variable. This meant that priorites changed
when the playbook was limited to only run on a subset of the hosts in
the "haproxy" group (eg. when reinstalling just one node).

This change replaces ansible_play_hosts by groups["haproxy"] so that the
priority calculation is stable as long as the set of haproxy nodes does
not change. It also simplifies the priority calculation without
changeing the result.

This change does not change the configuration in case the playbook is
run without --limit and ensures that the configuration does not change
if it is run with --limit.

To make sure the group vars resolution is not done in a all group,
which might have 0 haproxy nodes, we ensure the group vars are applied
properly to the haproxy group. This is a partial backport of the
patch to limit group_vars scoping [1].

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/85501cbf263029cfd5be44b9274113e4e5e4b6f8#diff-849f58a4930e8d8f73fd8310002552a9

Co-Authored-By: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>
Change-Id: I378351954fbed7b1fc31303c60e4575ddad9cf1d
(cherry picked from commit 78ed74957dfbd1bb151d0e6b5187fa0c263881ad)

commit_message:
Rename python-openstacksdk to openstacksdk

The git repo is being renamed today, so we should update this doc
string. Also, correct the description. SDK is a single library, not a
collection of libraries.

commit_message:
Set volume catalog type to volumev3

The cinder v1 API was removed in the queens release. The default
registered catalog type for the latest supported API is volumev3 and
should be used when performing tests against cinder.

Change-Id: Ia181d44ae6c307e5529fce763f700b51990ca5fa

commit_message:
Use addCleanup to detach volume instead of explicit detach

Cinder volume delete [1] is executed during resource cleanup.
So, if test fails due to some reason then it tries to delete a volume
which is "in-use" state. Detach volume should be executed before
trying to delete the volume. This patch adds nova_detach volume
as a cleanup task.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/barbican-tempest-plugin/blob/a6d945d8e677dedf73ccb7b2f7271e8fc96836be/barbican_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/manager.py#L229

Change-Id: I3457bb6fc22a7bb6a32c8d6f4ea5879aeb8d43c5
Related-Bug: #1755485

commit_message:
Enable hacking-extensions H204, H205

This patch enable extensions:
- H204: Use assert(Not)Equal to check for equality.
- H205: Use assert(Greater|Less)(Equal) for comparison.

Change-Id: Ice22442e4212784acd01dec045ecc438611155b7

commit_message:
Change memcache_socket_timeout to a float

It's not unusual to set 0.25 as a socket_timeout value, and this was
not possible. This can have a dramatic impact for performance when one
memcached server is down, especially when keystone is involved.

Change-Id: I01356b7873ad78cb38779f5c5ddd2b932889c911
Partial-Bug: #1731921
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.cache refs/changes/53/519353/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Revert "Consolidate admin guide and configuration guide"

This reverts commit a869abf951cef63548f92115cd46e7b80ef12c85.

Actually, we need to have both admin guide and configuration
guide because openstack manual will link to these two guides
respectively.

Change-Id: I1dc4ae9b0258afdc14efdce5664ffb0c7984124d

commit_message:
Removing deprecated function 'IPWrapper.get_namespaces()'

'IPWrapper.get_namespaces()' is deprecated in version 'Queens'
and was marked to be removed 'Rocky'.
This patch removes it and switches to use
'neutron.agent.linux.ip_lib.list_network_namespaces' instead.

Change-Id: I3af91c67e55279f4503499ade49ed0d02c57b9b5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/25/557125/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Note that stable branches have their own definitions.

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I5352398603e5755d46c9c033b05af637e379eea0
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Stop running get-ansible-role-requirements with -vvv

It generates a lot of console spam and adds very little value to
clone the roles with verbose every time.

Change-Id: If66a4d09dda8bab477c8f8aa8d5cefee7db7ddd9

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

In some part in the code we import objects. In the Openstack style guidelines
they recommend to import only modules. [1]: "Do not import objects, only modules".

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/hacking/0.10.3/

Change-Id: I7766149b0b74b745f73cd26f6f2352042b0ab570

commit_message:
make the --reqs arg to project-requirements-change.py useful

The --reqs argument was not being used which made it difficult to run
the script locally to test it.

This change passes the directory given to --reqs as the requirements
repository directory so that in local mode the repository can live
anywhere.

The default is still set to the location used on the CI nodes.

Change-Id: Id812628345313b781d65140bb3c25adf1eb00bc5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

Signed-off-by: Yuanbin.Chen <cybing4@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Kubernetes: Fix cluster database get return error

kubernetes auth use 'user' and 'project' create context,
but the parameter was modify 'user_id' and 'project_id'.
So, the database get data auth faild.

Change-Id: I366aee582ece6291494b04329f2f14e4491edc0a
Signed-off-by: Yuanbin.Chen <cybing4@gmail.com>

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I72fd5f8c87133713cd272de210b7e957880f48f9
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Consolidate admin guide and configuration guide

Both admin guide and configuration guide are targeting for the
same group of readers. There is no need to separate these two guides.
Move all contents under doc/source/admin to doc/source/configuration

commit_message:
use multiprovidernet api definition from neutron-lib

The multiprovidernet API extension's definition was rehomed into
neutron-lib with If3367e6a14074a6225bba527e8f7e38c51280f85 and will be
consumed in neutron via I12c15c360f8bf5a45fbe70e5ed1202ef0e7ec0f0

This patch switches the code over to use neutron-lib's multiprovidernet
API definition rather than neutron's extension.

Change-Id: I17350e143beb8ff1cc4ea80b48caa9f9b080cdb3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-midonet refs/changes/05/535505/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron_lib.api.definitions import multiprovidernet as mpnet_apidef segments = network.get(mpnet_apidef.SEGMENTS)
deleted_lines: from neutron.extensions import multiprovidernet as mpnet segments = network.get(mpnet.SEGMENTS)

commit_message:
ansible-role-requirements: Add common python_venv_build role

In order to allow tests to work as the use of the common
role is implemented in the various roles, we pre-implement
the addition of the role into the a-r-r file.

Change-Id: I51d6a2172b3d2cce8b20591e77f62b75ee336b39
Implements: blueprint python-build-install-simplification
Signed-off-by: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun refs/changes/88/556088/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: What is Zun? ============ For End Users ============= As an end user of Zun, you'll use Zun to create and manage containerized workload with either tools or the API directly. Tools for using Zun ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ * `Horizon <https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/user/>`_: The official web UI for the OpenStack Project. * `OpenStack Client <https://docs.openstack.org/python-openstackclient/latest/>`_: The official CLI for OpenStack Projects. You should use this as your CLI for most things, it includes not just Zun commands but also commands for most of the projects in OpenStack. * `Zun Client <https://docs.openstack.org/python-novaclient/latest/user/shell.html>`_: For some very advanced features (or administrative commands) of Zun you may need to use Zun client. It is still supported, but the ``openstack`` cli is recommended. Writing to the API ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ All end user (and some administrative) features of Zun are exposed via a REST API, which can be used to build more complicated logic or automation with Zun. This can be consumed directly, or via various SDKs. The following resources will help you get started with consuming the API directly. * `API Reference <http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/application-container/>`_: The complete reference for the REST API, including all methods and request / response parameters and their meaning. * :doc:`Compute API Microversion History </reference/api-microversion-history>`: The compute API evolves over time through `Microversions <https://developer.openstack.org/api-guide/compute/microversions.html>`_. This provides the history of all those changes. Consider it a "what's new" in the compute API.

commit_message:
install-guide: add steps to configure rootwrap

We need to configure rootwrap to start privsep daemon that is
used to execute privilege commands. Otherwise, all the shell
commands are not going to work.

Related-Bug: #1749342
Change-Id: I91e55f292e1ae247081e5728df70da81207e44b8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zun refs/changes/78/555978/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # su -s /bin/sh -c "cp etc/zun/rootwrap.conf \ /etc/zun/rootwrap.conf" zun # su -s /bin/sh -c "mkdir -p /etc/zun/rootwrap.d" zun # su -s /bin/sh -c "cp etc/zun/rootwrap.d/* \ /etc/zun/rootwrap.d/" zun #. Configure sudoers for ``zun`` users: .. code-block:: console # echo "zun ALL=(root) NOPASSWD: /usr/local/bin/zun-rootwrap \ /etc/zun/rootwrap.conf *" | sudo tee /etc/sudoers.d/zun-rootwrap

subject: Add functools.wraps decorator to rbac_rule_validation
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-20 21:57:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/patrole/commit/1174d7f736922843b043a3a5d62540e5a38b16c8', 'message': 'Fix testtools.testcase.attr interaction with rbac decorator

This is to fix the testtools.testcase.attr interaction between
the RBAC rule validation decorator. More specifically, the
@decorators.idempotent_id decorator from tempest.lib is conflicting
with the RBAC test role attribute that is injected as well
during a call to rbac_rule_validation.action decorator. This
conflict occurs when the rbac_rule_validation.action decorator
is above the decorators.idempotent_id decorator -- in this case
the idempotent ID is lost and replaced by the RBAC test role
(if the order is switched both attributes are printed out).

This fixes this issue so that, no matter the order, both attributes
are printed out. This is accomplished via functools.wraps [0].

Also cleans up some decorator code in rbac_rule_validation by
using @decorators.attr(type=role) which is cleaner than the
present implementation.

[0] https://docs.python.org/2/library/functools.html#functools.wraps

commit_message:
Add functools.wraps decorator to rbac_rule_validation

This adds functools.wraps [0] to rbac_rule_validation decorator.
"This takes a function used in a decorator and adds the functionality
of copying over the function name, docstring, arguments list, etc." which
is quite convenient [1].

Also stops adding the role as a testcase attribute which can cause
filtering issues via regular expressions when the role doesn't match
the role in tempest.conf under ``[patrole].rbac_test_role``.

[0] https://docs.python.org/2/library/functools.html#functools.wraps
[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/308999/what-does-functools-wraps-do

Change-Id: I8fde00e4f9332ba9b9ea94edc714d87ab9e1b851
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/patrole refs/changes/19/554719/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from tempest.lib.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.lib import decorators @mock.patch.object(decorators, 'testtools', autospec=True) @mock.patch.object(rbac_rv, 'policy_authority', autospec=True) def test_rule_validation_testtools_decorator(self, mock_authority, mock_testtools): """Test ``testtools.testcase.attr`` decorator is called correctly.""" self.useFixture( fixtures.ConfPatcher(rbac_test_role='test_role', group='patrole')) test_uuid = data_utils.rand_uuid() expected_calls = [ mock.call('test_role'), mock.call('id-%s' % test_uuid) ] # Do this to avoid __name__ error with mocking. mock_testtools.testcase.attr.return_value.return_value.__name__ = ( 'mock_test_func') # Verify that testtools.testcase.attr is called with the idempotent ID # as well as the RBAC test role. @rbac_rv.action(mock.sentinel.service, mock.sentinel.action) @decorators.idempotent_id(test_uuid) def test_policy(*args): pass test_policy(self.mock_test_args) for mock_call in expected_calls: self.assertIn(mock_call, mock_testtools.testcase.attr.mock_calls) # Swap the order of the decorators and try again. @decorators.idempotent_id(test_uuid) @rbac_rv.action(mock.sentinel.service, mock.sentinel.action) def test_policy(*args): pass test_policy(self.mock_test_args) for mock_call in expected_calls: self.assertIn(mock_call, mock_testtools.testcase.attr.mock_calls)

added_lines: import copy def test_rules_lifecycle(self): PRIORITY = 32768 TABLE = 16 attr = self.generate_device_details() device = self.manage_device(attr) test_cases = { constants.IP_VERSION_4: [ { 'from': '1.1.1.1', 'to': '8.8.8.0/24' }, { 'from': '1.1.1.1', 'iif': device.name, 'to': '7.7.7.0/24' } ], constants.IP_VERSION_6: [ { 'from': 'abcd::1', 'to': '1234::/64' }, { 'from': 'abcd::1', 'iif': device.name, 'to': '4567::/64' } ] } expected_rules = { constants.IP_VERSION_4: [ { 'from': '1.1.1.1', 'to': '8.8.8.0/24', 'priority': str(PRIORITY), 'table': str(TABLE), 'type': 'unicast' }, { 'from': '0.0.0.0/0', 'to': '7.7.7.0/24', 'iif': device.name, 'priority': str(PRIORITY), 'table': str(TABLE), 'type': 'unicast' } ], constants.IP_VERSION_6: [ { 'from': 'abcd::1', 'to': '1234::/64', 'priority': str(PRIORITY), 'table': str(TABLE), 'type': 'unicast' }, { 'from': '::/0', 'to': '4567::/64', 'iif': device.name, 'priority': str(PRIORITY), 'table': str(TABLE), 'type': 'unicast', } ] } ip_rule = ip_lib.IPRule(namespace=device.namespace) for ip_version, test_case in test_cases.items(): for rule in test_case: kwargs = copy.copy(rule) src = kwargs.pop('from') ip_rule.rule.add( src, table=TABLE, priority=PRIORITY, **kwargs) rules = ip_rule.rule.list_rules(ip_version) for expected_rule in expected_rules[ip_version]: self.assertIn(expected_rule, rules) for rule in test_case: kwargs = copy.copy(rule) src = kwargs.pop('from') ip_rule.rule.delete( src, table=TABLE, priority=PRIORITY, **kwargs) rules = ip_rule.rule.list_rules(ip_version) for expected_rule in expected_rules[ip_version]: self.assertNotIn(expected_rule, rules) class IpRuleTestCase(IpLibTestFramework): def setUp(self): super(IpRuleTestCase, self).setUp() self.namespace = utils.get_rand_name() ip = ip_lib.IPWrapper(namespace=self.namespace) ip.netns.add(self.namespace) self.addCleanup(ip.netns.delete, self.namespace)

commit_message:
add check before adding cpus to cpuset_reserved

There are some cases where None value is set to cpuset_reserved in
InstanceNUMATopology at _numa_fit_instance_cell() function in
hardware.py. However, libvirt driver treat cpuset_reserved value
as an iterate object when it constructs xml configuration.

To avoid a risk to get an error in libvirt driver, this patch adds
a check to see if the value is not None before adding the cpus
for emulator threads.

Change-Id: Iab3d950c4f4138118ac6a9fd98407eaadcb24d9e
Closes-Bug: #1746674

commit_message:
Fix nova profile get old image attribute

When nova profile execute update_image operation, the
old_image use profile image attribute.

However, the image of nova server does not guarantee that
it has not been modified by other components. So, the
old_image it should be the image attribute contained in server.

Change-Id: If68c54e67fccb3ec186831aa578f45a11007357d
Signed-off-by: Yuanbin.Chen <cybing4@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Non-unique network names in Servers IPs API response

Report correct server IP information when multiple networks
with the same name are used in VM. This spec proposes to
group VM networks using their IDs rater than names in
Server IPs API resource.

APIImpact

Spec for blueprint servers-ips-non-unique-network-names

Partial-Bug: #1708316
Change-Id: I1b13ed3bfc647b1b85e1535bc17c06bde0fe0d24
Signed-off-by: Maciej Kucia <maciej@kucia.net>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/92/521392/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================ Support non-unique network names in Servers IPs API response ============================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/servers-ips-non-unique-network-names Report correct server IP information when multiple networks with the same name are used in VM. This spec proposes to group VM networks using their IDs rater than names in Server IPs API resource. Problem description =================== Neutron allows multiple networks with the same name. Nova allows adding multiple networks to a VM. When two networks with the same name are added to a VM and Servers IPs API request is made then incorrect information is returned. Response is the same as if there would be a single network with multiple IP addresses. .. code-block:: javascript // GET /servers/68c1b82f-adf2-4b71-a411-0b70da3c1748/ips { "addresses": { "testnet1": [ { "OS-EXT-IPS-MAC:mac_addr": "fa:16:3e:65:83:12", "version": 4, "addr": "192.168.0.12", "OS-EXT-IPS:type": "fixed" }, { "OS-EXT-IPS-MAC:mac_addr": "fa:16:3e:7c:67:72", "version": 4, "addr": "192.168.1.4", "OS-EXT-IPS:type": "fixed" } ] } } Instead, the response should indicate that there are two networks with single address each. Additionally network label shall be preserved. .. code-block:: javascript // GET /servers/68c1b82f-adf2-4b71-a411-0b70da3c1748/ips { "addresses":{ "b7388c79-b206-4ddf-9d75-95ec4488b906":{ "name":"testnet1", "ips":[ { "OS-EXT-IPS-MAC:mac_addr":"fa:16:3e:65:83:12", "version":4, "addr":"192.168.0.12", "OS-EXT-IPS:type":"fixed" } ] }, "b69db569-85b3-4fd6-b053-11be7d23fbc6":{ "name":"testnet1", "ips":[ { "OS-EXT-IPS-MAC:mac_addr":"fa:16:3e:7c:67:72", "version":4, "addr":"192.168.1.4", "OS-EXT-IPS:type":"fixed" } ] } } } Consequently request for specific network shall be altered from:: /servers/{server_id}/ips/{network_label} to:: /servers/{server_id}/ips/{network_id} Use Cases --------- * As an API user, querying server IP information. Proposed change =============== This spec propose to fix this bug as microversion by changing response schema and resource path. The legacy API won't be fixed as the change affects API consumers. Alternatives ------------ * Do not allow adding network with the same name as already existing ones * Report server IPs as an array, not dict Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- 2 changes to API by new microversion in v2.55 API. Change resource path from:: /servers/{server_id}/ips/{network_label} to:: /servers/{server_id}/ips/{network_id} Change schema of ``/servers/{server_id}/ips`` resource to: * group networks by IDs * preserve network name in the network group .. code-block:: javascript { "addresses":{ "b7388c79-b206-4ddf-9d75-95ec4488b906":{ "name":"testnet1", "ips":[ { "OS-EXT-IPS-MAC:mac_addr":"fa:16:3e:65:83:12", "version":4, "addr":"192.168.0.12", "OS-EXT-IPS:type":"fixed" } ] } } } Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignees: Jonghan Park <jhan12.park@samsung.com> Maciej Kucia <maciej@kucia.net> Work Items ---------- * Fix the API by new microversion * Reflect API changes in nova-client * Reflect API changes in documentation Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Tests shall be updated to reflect API changes. Documentation Impact ==================== Update the `api-ref`_ to reflect new API schema and paths. References ========== * https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1708316 * https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#servers-ips-servers-ips History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Queens - Introduced

commit_message:
Moving the Communication slides to a new section

This change copies the communication slides of the upstream
institute to a communication section in the contributors
portal.
Also it adds a subchapter about Ask OpenStack.

Story: 2001622
Task: 6601
Task: 6599
Task: 6600

Signed-off-by: Gergely Csatari <gergely.csatari@nokia.com>

Change-Id: I02e43eba915ee4511f25cced9172c0ffe7314107
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/contributor-guide refs/changes/09/549009/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ############# Communication ############# Ways to Communicate in OpenStack ================================ - Talking in IRC Channels & Meetings - Wiki Pages - Etherpads - Mailing Lists IRC Channels ============ - Project Channels: - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC - Each project and working group has its own channel - The common syntax: #openstack-<name-of-project> - Meeting Channels: - #openstack-meeting, #openstack-meeting-cp, etc. - Meetings typically follow an agenda - Most projects use the OpenStack wiki to post agendas - IRC meetings: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/ - Others: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Meetings .. note:: There are a finite number of meeting channels so that meetings are spread around. This is enforced by infra. The #openstack-meeting-cp channel is special in that it is dedicated to cross project efforts. IRC Logs ======== - Logs of meetings and channels are archived so that they can be referenced later on - Meeting Logs: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/ - Channel Logs: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/ Wiki Pages ========== - Each project and working group also has its own wiki page - https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Main_Page - Good source of info about when and in what channel regular meetings are held - Generally has information about who the PTL and cores are Etherpads ========= - Common place to have people in a project collaborate on larger projects and planning of events - No master list of etherpads - harder to find what you are looking for without having looked at it before or without asking for the URL - `https://etherpad.openstack.org <https://etherpad.openstack.org>`_ Mailing Lists (ML) ================== - More than 40 different ML's - http://lists.openstack.org/cgi-bin/mailman/listinfo - Way for people to communicate to a larger group than those that are on IRC - All emails are archived - The `Mailing Lists <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Mailing_Lists>`_ wiki page describes how to subscribe to a list and describes some popular lists

commit_message:
Add serial numbers for local disks

It is possible to assign a serial number to virtual hard disks which
can be queried by the guest operating system. We currently do this for
attached volumes, but we don't do it for local disks: local root
disks, ephemerals, or swap disks.

Previously-approved: Queens
Blueprint: local-disk-serial-numbers

Change-Id: I6f11e0344db78b9bd9e7406dfd07ab2e3f06eddf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/65/556565/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Expose persistent serial numbers for local disks ================================================ https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/local-disk-serial-numbers It is possible to assign a serial number to virtual hard disks which can be queried by the guest operating system. We currently do this for attached volumes, but we don't do it for local disks: local root disks, ephemerals, or swap disks. The primary user-facing purpose of this feature is to expose a persistent serial number for local disks to guests. Problem description =================== The presentation of disks to a guest operating system is inherently non-deterministic. The most robust way to address disks is by some persistent property of the disk, serial number being the most convenient. The problem is most acute for attached volumes, and we already expose the volume id as the serial number of a disk. For robustness and consistency we should extend this feature to cover local disks. Use Cases --------- As a user running windows guests, I need to avoid having activation issues due to a lack of a stable disk serial number. As an admin, I need to be able to migrate windows guests to address maintenance needs in the datacenter without risking de-activating customer windows instances because disk serial numbers are not stable. As a user, I want a common mechanism to identify both attached volumes and ephemeral disks for my workload. Proposed change =============== This spec proposes a new contract with virt drivers. For drivers which implement stable local disk serial numbers, the following will be true: * Local root disks, ephemeral, and swap disks will all have a serial number. * This serial number will not change for the lifetime of an instance. * For tagged disks, this serial number will be exposed to the guest in device metadata. The method used to generate and persist local disk serial numbers is not defined, and may differ between drivers as long as the above remain true. For example, the ironic driver would meet the first 2 points automatically by the virtue of physical disks having persistent and stable serial numbers. The ironic driver can implement this spec simply by exposing these serial numbers in device metadata for tagged local disks. The spec proposes a specific scheme to implement the above for the libvirt driver, which may also be of use to other virt drivers. All disks attached to an instance, except config disks, have a block device mapping, which has a persistent uuid. We will present this uuid to the guest as the serial number of local disks. For volumes we will continue to present volume id as we do currently. Serial numbers will be exposed to virt drivers by adding a serial field to DriverBlockDevice. This will additionally require us to expose the block device mapping of local root disks to virt drivers, which we do not currently do. We will do this by adding an additional field to the block_device_info dict, meaning that existing drivers which know nothing about this field will not be affected by it. Alternatives ------------ Other ways to generate a persistent serial number for local disks were considered. These included: * Using a combination of instance uuid and a driver-specific disk identifier * Using a combination of instance uuid and bdm id The former was rejected as being driver-specific. The latter was rejected as it would change should we ever implement the ability to migrate between cells. Data model impact ----------------- A uuid field was added to BDMs during Queens for this feature. To complete this process, in the Rocky cycle we should add a not null constraint to the uuid field, and remove python code which handles null uuid fields in the database. REST API impact --------------- None. Security impact --------------- None. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ None. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: mbooth@redhat.com Work Items ---------- * Expose local root disks to virt drivers via block_device_info. * Add serial field to DriverBlockDevice with the existing behaviour for volumes, and the new bdm uuid for local disks. * Update libvirt driver to use DriverBlockDevice.serial for all disks. Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Unit testing should cover: * block_device_info contains root disk for both boot-from-volume and local root. * DriverVolumeBlockDevice and its subclasses should contain a serial field containing the volume id. * Other DriverBlockDevice subclasses should contain a serial field contining the BDM uuid. Tempest testing should cover: * Local disks presented to guest have a serial number if they are present in device metadata. Documentation Impact ==================== This is a user-visible change. Documentation covering device tagging should be updated to reflect the ability to tag local disks. References ========== None.

commit_message:
Don't inform root about FOUND shard ranges

There is no need to tell the root container about shard ranges that
have been newly found. The root is not interested in ranges until
their shard containers have been created.

Change-Id: I1b76095108799566e31804c9a17b16e92f19e0f6

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-25 15:53:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/cbdb8135b0f618e0faf68f7ed5be5616e004f96e', 'message': 'Only use estimated progress in find_shard_ranges if reliable

Change-Id: Ib74e2efc4e854a2dd95101777bca114a7865fba7
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-03-26 13:30:28.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/container/test_backend.py', 'swift/container/backend.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/5d762e5c836d990de1134545695bf391fc647115', 'message': "Only use estimated progress in find_shard_ranges if reliable

Before, ContainerBroker.find_shard_ranges assumed that any existing
shard ranges had same size as the shard_size passed to the current
invocation of the method when estimating progress.  This could lead to
undesirable results if different shard sizes were used for different
invocation, particularly if the shard size increased to make the
progress appear larger than reality.

With this patch the estimate of progress is based on the actual sizes
of previously found shard ranges. For this to be accurate, previously
found ranges must have remained in FOUND state i.e. no shard container
has yet been created and no newer object updates made to the
shards. If this is not true then the progress estimate is considered
unreliable and defaults to zero.

A TODO is removed which suggested that the object_count might be
refreshed before processing each found range upper. This does not seem
necessary because find_shard_ranges() is called after container has
moved to SHARDING state such that the db being scanned is effectively
'read-only'.

Change-Id: Ib74e2efc4e854a2dd95101777bca114a7865fba7
"}]
commit_message:
Only use estimated progress in find_shard_ranges if reliable

Before, ContainerBroker.find_shard_ranges assumed that any existing
shard ranges had same size as the shard_size passed to the current
invocation of the method when estimating progress.  This could lead to
undesirable results if different shard sizes were used for different
invocation, particularly if the shard size increased to make the
progress appear larger than reality.

With this patch the estimate of progress is based on the actual sizes
of previously found shard ranges. For this to be accurate, previously
found ranges must have remained in FOUND state i.e. no shard container
has yet been created and no newer object updates made to the
shards. If this is not true then the progress estimate is considered
unreliable and defaults to zero.

A TODO is removed which suggested that the object_count might be
refreshed before processing each found range upper. This does not seem
necessary because find_shard_ranges() is called after container has
moved to SHARDING state such that the db being scanned is effectively
'read-only'.

Change-Id: Ib74e2efc4e854a2dd95101777bca114a7865fba7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/61/556261/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: progress_reliable = True if all([sr.state == ShardRange.FOUND for sr in existing_ranges]): progress = sum([sr.object_count for sr in existing_ranges]) else: # else: object count in existing shard ranges may have changed # since they were found so progress cannot be reliably # calculated; that's ok, progress is used for optimisation not # correctness progress_reliable = False if progress + shard_size >= sub_broker._get_info()['object_count']: # bother with db query; use fresh sample of object_count each # time in case objects have been added if progress_reliable: # object count may include misplaced objects, so the final # shard size may not be accurate until cleaved, but at # least the sum of shard sizes will equal the unsharded # object_count shard_size = object_count - progress
deleted_lines: # TODO: if config shard_size changes between calls to this method # then this estimation of progress will be WRONG - we need to # either record progress in db or record snapshot of shard_size in # each ShardRange and sum them here, OR ditch progress altogether # and lose the optimisation on finding last shard range progress = len(existing_ranges) * shard_size if progress + shard_size >= object_count: # bother with db query # TODO: should we refresh object count before this test or are # we safe assuming that no updates to the container will be # made while we're scanning? # object count may include misplaced objects, so the final # shard size may not be accurate until cleaved, but at least # the sum of shard sizes will equal the unsharded object_count shard_size = object_count - progress

commit_message:
Stop passing own_shard_range to _misplaced_objects

Move toward a consistent interface to the methods that implement each
phase of sharding i.e. just pass in a ContainerBroker instance.

The change also avoids any potential for a stale copy of
own_shard_range to be used in _misplaced_objects.

Furthermore, the change simplifies testing. It is no longer necessary
to create an own shard range instance simply to pass it to
_misplaced_objects() in tests.

There was previously some efficiency gained from fetching a single
instance of own_shard_range which was passed to _misplaced_objects and
used to evaluate the state of the sharding process. This is traded off
for the advantages described above.

Change-Id: I96ec8a06c859d49823ec97314011694eac87cb16
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/80/556180/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _misplaced_objects(self, broker): own_shard_range = broker.get_own_shard_range() self._misplaced_objects(broker) self._find_sharding_candidates( broker, shard_ranges=[broker.get_own_shard_range()]) own_shard_range = broker.get_own_shard_range()
deleted_lines: def _misplaced_objects(self, broker, own_shard_range): :param own_shard_range: A ShardRange describing the namespace for this broker own_shard_range = broker.get_own_shard_range() self._misplaced_objects(broker, own_shard_range) if self._find_sharding_candidates( broker, shard_ranges=[own_shard_range]): own_shard_range = broker.get_own_shard_range()

Adding ETC binaries was a stop gap measure until packages were

Also using the mirror on tarballs.o.o was unreliable so these binaries
are cached in the nodepool images as described in[1].  Having this
setting in d-g makes more work than is needed in the near term.
Removing it does introduce a new failure mode if an etcd version is
used in devstack but not yet cacched in the image.

Change-Id: I2a6649ae3094ca65aa31798ee9bddf2fcdd49260

commit_message:
Remove setting of ETCD_DOWNLOAD_URL

Adding ETC binaries was a stop gap measure until packages were
available.  With the impending release of bionic that'll be soon :)

Also using the mirror on tarballs.o.o was unreliable so these binaries
are cached in the nodepool images as described in[1].  Having this
setting in d-g makes more work than is needed in the near term.
Removing it does introduce a new failure mode if an etcd version is
used in devstack but not yet cacched in the image.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-infra/2018-March/005871.html

Change-Id: I2a6649ae3094ca65aa31798ee9bddf2fcdd49260
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/88/556688/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Only delete misplaced objects that were moved
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-23 17:26:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/d2bd3d53031f22cff5b34d790963e4f6ea7fe43f', 'message': 'Only delete misplaced objects that were moved
