commit_message:
Only delete misplaced objects that were moved

Before, we read any misplaced objects from a range of the source db,
replicated them, then removed everything in that range from the source
db. Any objects being merged between the read and the removal would be
lost.

With this patch, two safety measures are added:

First, the broker info is sampled before objects are read. The info is
annotated with the db max_row at that moment. Then, when objects are
removed, only rows up to the max row in the sampled broker info are
removed. Any new rows will be retained and dealt with on the next
cycle.  It is possible that new rows were in fact yielded and
replicated, but it is not certain, so they should not be removed. At
worst they will be replicated again on the next cycle and then
removed.

Second, before removing any rows, a check is made that the broker id
has not changed. If it has then no rows are removed.

Also add unit test for ContainerBroker.remove_objects().

Change-Id: I923c257996eb1bfd3aa17895616750461b3aee59
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/74/555874/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def remove_objects(self, lower, upper, storage_policy_index, max_row=None): :param max_row: if specified only rows less than or equal to max_row will be removed query_conditions = ['storage_policy_index = ?'] query_args = [storage_policy_index] if max_row: query_conditions.append('ROWID <= ?') query_args.append(str(max_row)) if lower: query_conditions.append('name > ?') query_args.append(str(lower)) if upper: query_conditions.append('name <= ?') query_args.append(str(upper)) query = 'DELETE FROM object WHERE deleted in (0, 1)' if query_conditions: query += ' AND ' + ' AND '.join(query_conditions)
deleted_lines: def remove_objects(self, lower, upper, storage_policy_index): query = ('DELETE FROM object WHERE deleted in (0, 1) ' 'AND storage_policy_index = ? AND name > ?') query_args = [storage_policy_index, lower] if upper: query += ' AND name <= ?' query_args.append(upper)

subject: Require sufficient replication of each cleaved shard range
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-15 11:21:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/aec267aa1a9a225a345ba0e6028a40c259b5072b', 'message': "Require sufficient replication of each cleaved shard range

Before, when cleaving shard ranges, the sharder created local db's for
each shard range and spawned a thread to replicate them. There was no
check that the replication of each db was successful.

Now, each cleaved db is replicated in turn and cleaving does not
progress until each db has been sufficiently replicated. Replication
is considered sufficient if a quorum of replicas were sync'd. If the
sharding node happens to be one of the cleave db's primaries then that
counts as a sync'd replica.

For example, with a 3 replica container ring, replication is
considered sufficient if the cleaved db was sync'd with at least 2
other nodes, or if the cleaved db is on one of it's primaries and also
sync'd with one other node.

commit_message:
Require sufficient replication of each cleaved shard range

Before, when cleaving shard ranges, the sharder created local db's for
each shard range and spawned a thread to replicate them. There was no
check that the replication of each db was successful.

Now, each cleaved db is replicated in turn and cleaving does not
progress until each db has been sufficiently replicated. Replication
is considered sufficient if a quorum of replicas were sync'd. If the
sharding node happens to be one of the cleave db's primaries then that
counts as a sync'd replica.

For example, with a 3 replica container ring, replication is
considered sufficient if the cleaved db was sync'd with at least 2
other nodes, or if the cleaved db is on one of it's primaries and also
sync'd with one other node.

Change-Id: I1653ed69c51c9789e2ef19fae762a96a63139766
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/37/553337/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: config_float_value, config_positive_int_value, FileLikeIter, list_from_csv, \ quorum_size self.stats['containers_sharded'] += 1 success, responses = self._replicate_object( new_part, new_broker.db_file, node_id) if (not success and sum(responses) < quorum_size(self.ring.replica_count)): # break because we don't want to progress the cleave cursor # until each shard range has been successfully cleaved self.logger.warning( 'Failed to sufficiently replicate cleaved shard %s for %s', shard_range, broker.path) break ranges_done.append(shard_range) self.logger.increment('cleaved') # cleaving complete
deleted_lines: config_float_value, config_positive_int_value, FileLikeIter, list_from_csv ranges_done.append(shard_range) self.cpool.spawn( self._replicate_object, new_part, new_broker.db_file, node_id) self.logger.increment('sharded') self.stats['containers_sharded'] += 1 # cleaving complete, reset cursor # TODO: a finite timeout might be a good idea self.cpool.waitall(None)

subject: Catch Errors When Nova API Microversions Are Not Supported
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-24 23:38:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/e91ad811ccaec95a982cc0b785c70ec84180340c', 'message': "Catch Errors When Nova API Microversions Are Not Supported

Throughout OpenStack, the eventlet library is used heavily
for threading. In this case, we use spawn_n() from
eventlet which does not return whether the method that was
wrapped with it raised an exception. Exceptions are instead
just printed to stderr. Many deployers are using simple
logging configurations that just log everything to a file.
This poses a problem because spawn_n() does not use standard
Python logging, but rather just prints a stack trace to stderr, like
this: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/master/eventlet/greenpool.py#L93

Any exceptions that get thrown in enventlet.spawn_n() are
not shown in log files that are setup with normal log
configurations that write to files. Deployers who have not been
heavily involved with a lot of upstream development or do not
know the internals of eventlet would think that there are no
errors when tailing their log files which makes debugging
problems extremely difficult. There are a few options
to make error handling better

1. Use spawn() instead of spawn_n(). spawn() returns a greenthread
object that would allow us to see the results of the call. We could
check the results and log a proper exception if we used spawn().
The problem is, this would incur a performance penalty as spawn()
is slower than spawn_n()

2. Expect deployers to write a custom log handler that will redirect
stderr to their log file

3. Use proper exception handling inside of the functions that are called
with spawn_n() so that exceptions we care about get caught and logged
correctly

My patch takes the option 3 approach. If deployers are not using a version of
Nova API on the backend that supports microversions, then the aggregate object
will not return a UUID which will cause an exception to be raised when we go
to associate the segment with the aggregate. This breaks the flow and the
resulting host aggregate will be empty which is useless. On top of that, most
deployers will never know because no errors get logged with Python's standard
logging framework when this happens.

Change-Id: I9c6151ffa90394612e7f81ededd4a309dd8ab7fb
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-03-25 23:54:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/54bf0440ae9d17f5152c865a6d039bf346d95014', 'message': "Catch Errors When Nova API Microversions Are Not Supported

"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2018-03-26 01:37:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/cc31b9b3d1f32bdbead20126707089b588c49f93', 'message': "Catch Errors When Nova API Microversions Are Not Supported

Throughout OpenStack, the eventlet library is used heavily
for threading. In this case, we use spawn_n() from
eventlet which does not return whether the method that was
wrapped with it raised an exception. Exceptions are instead
just printed to stderr. Many deployers are using simple
logging configurations that just log everything to a file.
This poses a problem because spawn_n() does not use standard
Python logging, but rather just prints a stack trace to stderr, like
this: https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/master/eventlet/greenpool.py#L93

Any exceptions that get thrown in enventlet.spawn_n() are
not shown in log files that are setup with normal log
configurations that write to files. Deployers who have not been
heavily involved with a lot of upstream development or do not
know the internals of eventlet would think that there are no
errors when tailing their log files which makes debugging
problems extremely difficult. There are a few options
to make error handling better

1. Use spawn() instead of spawn_n(). spawn() returns a greenthread
object that would allow us to see the results of the call. We could
check the results and log a proper exception if we used spawn().
The problem is, this would incur a performance penalty as spawn()
is slower than spawn_n()

2. Expect deployers to write a custom log handler that will redirect
stderr to their log file

3. Use proper exception handling inside of the functions that are called
with spawn_n() so that exceptions we care about get caught and logged
correctly

My patch takes the option 3 approach. If deployers are not using a version of
Nova API on the backend that supports microversions, then the aggregate object
will not return a UUID which will cause an exception to be raised when we go
to associate the segment with the aggregate. This breaks the flow and the
resulting host aggregate will be empty which is useless. On top of that, most
deployers will never know because no errors get logged with Python's standard
logging framework when this happens.

Change-Id: I9c6151ffa90394612e7f81ededd4a309dd8ab7fb

commit_message:
Catch Errors When Nova API Microversions Are Not Supported

Currently, errors related to lack of microversion support are completely
masked because of the way eventlet.spawn_n() works. These changes
improve error handling so that deployers are explicitly notified when
Nova API microversions are not supported. This is useful because without
microversion support, the entire flow will break and hosts will not be
associated with segments properly. Deployers will have no idea why
because errors are not printed to log files setup by the standard Python
logging framework.

Related-Bug: #1759004
Change-Id: I9c6151ffa90394612e7f81ededd4a309dd8ab7fb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/20/556120/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: self.p_client.associate_aggregates(segment_id, [aggregate.uuid]) except AttributeError: LOG.exception("An AttributeError was raised while attempting to " "associate host aggregates! This is likely because " "your nova API does not support microversions. " "Ensure your Nova API endpoint is using v2.1.")

commit_message:
Allow all pollsters can be specified when starting ceilometer-polling

For now, the pollsters in ipmi namespaces cannot be specified when
starting ceilometer-polling without --polling-namespaces specified, that
because the ceilometer-polling assume the default namespaces are:
['compute', 'central'], the 'ipmi' doesn't be included.

Change-Id: I8872132f41a7494de7d5226c34e61891cc562a03
Closes-Bug: #1603320
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/36/342636/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if pollster_list and not namespaces: namespaces = ['compute', 'central', 'ipmi'] else: namespaces = namespaces or ['compute', 'central']

commit_message:
Revert "Create ovs temp directories when using ovs"

This reverts commit 7ba9b763828155ba4ec639b92017061b013a2f5f.

Open vSwitch is creating the /var/run/openvswitch directory with the
correct permissions before the systemd services are started so we
shouldn't have to do that ourselves.

Closes-Bug: #1754139
Change-Id: If351f5562a6c0c6ec7404ee2a827772fed32b858

commit_message:
Set ubuntu-bionic as non-voting on zuul-jobs

This is preventing us from landing code, as since bionic isn't
released yet that is okay since we don't gate any projects.

The bionic issue looks to be around apt cache being stale.

Change-Id: Icfe6b7389f2e91021dca09c5c534448632974e01
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix 'pause' engine command

* Commands going after 'pause' in 'on-XXX' clauses
  were never processed after workflow resume. The
  solution is to introduce a notion of a workflow
  execution backlog where we can save these commands
  in a serialized form so that the engine dispatcher
  could see and process them after resume.
* Other minor changes

Change-Id: I963b5660daf528d1caf6a785311de4fb272cafd0
Closes-Bug: #1714054

commit_message:
Use hostvars to get ansible_default_ipv6

I think this is missing picking this up from hostvars, so always
assumes ipv4.

commit_message:
Storwize: check flashcopy_rate before mkfcmap

Configure flashcopy_rate in volume type, there is no value
checking before mkfcmap.

This patch adds flashcopy_rate checking before make fcmap.

Change-Id: I7823749bd8add3ce41e4b2862fd0f06dd0fa0888
Closes-Bug:  1753908
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/87/556387/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if flashcopy_rate not in range(1, 151): raise exception.InvalidInput( reason=_('The configured flashcopy rate should ' 'between 1 and 150.')) elif code_level < (7, 8, 1, 0) and flashcopy_rate > 100:

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I0ef8ed50f55fa905b6090805a3088fc5ab56906c
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
A keystone only controller deployment

Testing a very basic deployment to be
used with free-ipa, and upgrade ci.
There may be other valuable uses for this

commit_message:
deprecate old general configurations

In order to better support the growing list of
supported configurations we need to prune out the
older less tested configurations in src

Configurations required should be documented and
listed in https://docs.openstack.org/tripleo-quickstart/latest/feature-configuration.html

Related-To: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/553892/
Change-Id: I56fb4113d4615546ae4fb62e729b262fc985d0d1

commit_message:
Fixed the problem for SSL certificate access failure

When specify OPENSTACK_SSL_NO_VERIFY = False, monascaclient
throws an exception when access alarms, alarm definitions
and notifictions.  Changed parameter cert to verify so it
takes boolean or passes the certificate file.

Also added unit tests for api.client

Story: 2001601
Task: 6555

Change-Id: Ib068bdc3fae1ebdb2bda8d7b6c24a725cef5b24b
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/550130
(cherry picked from commit c347cd2bf4f3b3f02e41f07edbf7960ff59110cd)

added_lines: def _get_to_verify(insecure, cacert): to_verify = cacert if insecure: to_verify = False return to_verify to_verify = _get_to_verify(INSECURE, CACERT) verify=to_verify,

commit_message:
ansible-role-requirements: Add common python_venv_build role

In order to allow tests to work as the use of the common
role is implemented in the various roles, we pre-implement
the addition of the role into the a-r-r file.

subject: Fix health manager edge case with zombie amphora
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-27 19:06:51.000000000', 'files': ['octavia/tests/unit/controller/worker/test_controller_worker.py', 'octavia/controller/worker/controller_worker.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/78902ae5dc7cf9bd43b8e60bc6ab2fe87efa7e22', 'message': 'Fix health manager edge case with zombie amphora

There is a edge case where amphora may have been deleted, marked deleted in
our database, but still be running in nova. One example is an instance stuck
in nova "deleting" status. These can still report health heartbeats, but
we will see them as failed as they are reporting load balancing configuration
that we do not have a record for. This will lead to a failover to repair the
amphora, which will re-attempt the delete and reset the amphora health record.
Which can lead to another failover attempt.

This patch will log and leave the amphora as "busy" if a failover is attempted
on an amphora we show as "DELETED". This will prevent repeated failover
attempts on "DELETED" amphora that are still alive in the compute system.

It also fixes a mis-named mock object in a failover test.

Change-Id: I3397ffacf8e08964ecd4b47f2353542b6bc57645
(cherry picked from commit 1a35d6dc81b96b34f1b5251540afcbe62f2fb0d2)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix health manager edge case with zombie amphora

There is a edge case where amphora may have been deleted, marked deleted in
our database, but still be running in nova. One example is an instance stuck
in nova "deleting" status. These can still report health heartbeats, but
we will see them as failed as they are reporting load balancing configuration
that we do not have a record for. This will lead to a failover to repair the
amphora, which will re-attempt the delete and reset the amphora health record.
Which can lead to another failover attempt.

This patch will log and leave the amphora as "busy" if a failover is attempted
on an amphora we show as "DELETED". This will prevent repeated failover
attempts on "DELETED" amphora that are still alive in the compute system.

It also fixes a mis-named mock object in a failover test.

Change-Id: I3397ffacf8e08964ecd4b47f2353542b6bc57645
(cherry picked from commit 1a35d6dc81b96b34f1b5251540afcbe62f2fb0d2)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/17/557017/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._amphora_health_repo = repo.AmphoraHealthRepository() if amp.status == constants.DELETED: LOG.warning('Amphora %s is marked DELETED in the database ' 'but was submitted for failover. Marking it busy ' 'in the amphora health table to exclude it from ' 'health checks and skipping the failover.', amp.id) self._amphora_health_repo.update(db_apis.get_session(), amp.id, busy=True) return

commit_message:
Add spec for MFA auth receipts

Change-Id: Ia8f25cf84070c271fc2ffb9f8fd115f55b3e428e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone-specs refs/changes/70/553670/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================== Partial Auth Token ================== `partial-auth-token <https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/ partial-auth-token>`_ To provide proper usable multi-factor authentication (MFA) support in OpenStack we need a token type that can be used for a challenge response. Problem Description =================== As of Ocata Keystone supports setting auth rules on a given user and requiring them to auth with potentially multiple auth methods. This is a good implementation of MFA, but the problem rests in a user or service knowing ahead of time how they need to auth. Most standard MFA systems are challenge response based. You auth with one of your factors, then are given a token of that partial authentication, which you can return along with the missing pieces. Keystone needs such a mechanism because without it we can't realistically consume MFA anywhere else in OpenStack in a manner that makes sense for users. The original proposal for MFA in Keystone actually included this concept but was never implemented: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/multi-factor-authn The concept of a half-token was discussed, but it never really got implemented in a way we could use for MFA. Proposed Change =============== The proposal is to add a new token type that exists solely for the challenge response process. When a user successfully authenticates with one of their many auth rules, we can infer that they are who they say they are, and then return to them a token that contains information about missing auth rules. This new token would allow no API interaction, but it would be proof that certain auth methods have been completed. An example response:: { "token": { "methods": [ "password" ], "required_auth_plugins": [ ['password', 'totp'] ], "expires_at": "2015-11-06T15:32:17.893769Z", "user": { "domain": { "id": "default", "name": "Default" }, "id": "423f19a4ac1e4f48bbb4180756e6eb6c", "name": "admin", "password_expires_at": null }, "audit_ids": [ "ZzZwkUflQfygX7pdYDBCQQ" ], "issued_at": "2015-11-06T14:32:17.893797Z" } } By knowing what auth rules are needed we can build tools and libraries that after a partially successful authentication can inquired about the missing pieces. This allows Horizon to build GUI based on the returned token, and not require the user to reenter their password. Alternatives ------------ In Ocata when the auth rules were introduced the alternative was put forward to simply change the error messages of the failed MFA auth to inform the user why their auth failed. Any services could also parse the errors and infer what the missing auth was and generate GUI or cli queries back to the user. This doesn't work for a few reasons. It relies on parsing error messages rather than sensible returned data structures, and it requires that for every auth attempt ALL methods are supplied. This means an MFA attempt for password+totp needs to cache the password to resubmit it when it is determined that totp is also needed. For Horizon that doesn't work. We can't cache the password serverside, and we shouldn't store it in a cookie or in browser really, and asking the user to supply their password again isn't good UX. This alternative also isn't a real challenge response. Security Impact --------------- A user who authenticates with one successful method now knows what auth rules can be used for a given user. This isn't particularly unsafe, as while they know the rules, they can't auth with them. Additionally it is safe to assume that one successful auth method is enough to prove identity of the user, while not enough to satisfy authentication requirements. Notifications Impact -------------------- N/A Other End User Impact --------------------- Currently the auth rules are not supported anywhere other than the Keystone API itself. In a large part this is because there is no way to programmatically figure out missing auth rules after a failure. This change would alter the API response in that Keystone would now return a partial token rather than an error, but since no one is using this feature yet for good reasons it's a safe change. This change would require follow up in KeystoneAuth and other libraries to then lead into support for MFA in the OpenStackClient and Horizon. Performance Impact ------------------ N/A Other Deployer Impact --------------------- This would allow a much better MFA method going forward and allow us to expand on it in ways that would actually be useful to deployers. Developer Impact ---------------- This would only affect authentication workflows in OpenStack and any code dealing with them. This change though will give us a good programmatic way to deal with MFA and will mean those tools can handle failures in a useful way. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Unknown as yet, but I'm (adriant) willing to do it with guidance. Work Items ---------- #. Add support for the new token type to Keystone and change the auth plugin layer to return the new token on one successful auth method out of configured rules rather than an error. #. Add support to KeystoneAuth to handle this correctly and infer from this token what other methods are needed, as well as adding proper Multi-Method support into KeystoneAuth. #. Work with the CLI and Dashboard teams to build support in for MFA using the changes made to KeystoneAuth. A potential follow up is a series of safe APIs for non-admins to manage their own auth rules. Dependencies ============ N/A Documentation Impact ==================== Will require extra documentation for new features, but no existing non-MFA auth paths will change. References ========== Please add any useful references here. You are not required to have any reference. Moreover, this specification should still make sense when your references are unavailable. Examples of what you could include are: * https://adam.younglogic.com/2012/10/multifactor-auth-and-keystone/ * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/keystone/+spec/multi-factor-authn * https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/ocata/per-user-auth-plugin-requirements.html

subject: Fix integer -> method conversion for python3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-22 15:40:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/95d0efb972a4bfe5d8681551a648f21f07fb5bbe', 'message': "WIP: Expose python3 bug when cache_on_issue is False

We have a method that takes an integer and re-inflates it into a list
of authentication methods. This is because it's more efficient to
pass around an integer in a token's payload than a list of strings.
During the token validation process, we take this integer and run it
through a little process to reinflate it's value to a list of auth
methods that were used to obtain the original token.

The re-inflation process doesn't actually work in python3 because
it is coded to expect division operations to return integers, which
is accurate for python2. Python3 returns floats when dividing two
integers, which doesn't work with the logic to re-inflate the auth
methods. For example, in python 3::

  >>> result = 5 / 4
  >>> result
  1.25
  >>> type(result)
  <class 'float'>

In python2:

  >>> result = 5 / 4
  >>> result
  1
  >>> type(result)
  <type 'int'>

You can recreate this by initiating the token validation process
and disabling the CONF.token.cache_on_issue configuration option.

Change-Id: I627c2b353da0c35bb23bb40542a880fc6bacc4aa

commit_message:
Fix integer -> method conversion for python3

We have a method that takes an integer and re-inflates it into a list
of authentication methods. This is because it's more efficient to
pass around an integer in a token's payload than a list of strings.
During the token validation process, we take this integer and run it
through a little process to reinflate it's value to a list of auth
methods that were used to obtain the original token.

The re-inflation process doesn't actually work in python3 because it
is coded to expect integers when dividing numbers, which is accurate
for python2. Python3 returns floats when dividing two integers, which
doesn't work with the logic to re-inflate the auth methods. For
example, in python 3::

  >>> result = 5 / 4
  >>> result
  1.25
  >>> type(result)
  <class 'float'>

In python2:

  >>> result = 5 / 4
  >>> result
  1
  >>> type(result)
  <type 'int'>

This commit introduces unit tests to prevent regression and includes
a fix so that the conversion works properly on python3.

Closes-Bug: 1758121
Change-Id: I627c2b353da0c35bb23bb40542a880fc6bacc4aa

commit_message:
Switch project neworks.ports to mock

In Python3, map() returns a map object. It is better to ensure to pass
an iterable object when the value is passed to another library.
_construct_parameters in networks/ports/workflows.py is updated.

Change-Id: I471a5620806b0b4e62604cc57dde2485fbdcf242
Partially-Implements: blueprint mock-framework-in-unit-tests

commit_message:
Make tags filter match subset rather than exact

Currently when using the "tags" filter to search projects by tag names,
the filter only matches projects that have an exact match. Projects that
contain the exact tags given, but with additional tags are excluded.
This behavior is not compatible with the use cases defined in both the
keystone[0] and api-wg[1] specs, notibly with the "tags" and "tags-any"
interaction.

This change makes it so that "tags" filtering will be performed by
matching a subset containing given tags against projects, rather than
exact matching. This allows the "tags" and "tags-any" filters to work as
described in both [0] and [1].

[0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/queens/project-tags.html
[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/api-wg/guidelines/tags.html#filtering-and-searching-by-tags

Co-Authored By: Nicolas Helgeson <nh202b@att.com>

Closes-Bug: #1756190
Change-Id: I632efdf0af2969be0a59dc5928a6c036eeca6051

Removes an inappropriate directory space check when copying an image to
a volume. In the general case, "dest" is a block device, so it's not
appropriate to check for space in the directory containing "dest". One
exception may be the NFS driver, where dest actually is a file, but that
should be handled elsewhere (if necessary). This check has always been

Change-Id: Ie5eba32f92eb1740554bfc44baf612e326d6fde5

commit_message:
Remove inappropriate directory space check

Removes an inappropriate directory space check when copying an image to
a volume. In the general case, "dest" is a block device, so it's not
appropriate to check for space in the directory containing "dest". One
exception may be the NFS driver, where dest actually is a file, but that
should be handled elsewhere (if necessary). This check has always been
inappropriate, but was silently ineffective due to a unit-comparison bug
that was recently fixed.

Change-Id: Ie5eba32f92eb1740554bfc44baf612e326d6fde5
Closes-Bug: 1756425

commit_message:
Correctly set NeutronMl2PluginBase for OVN scenario

OVN configuration was not done when deployed with
scenario007 as default for NeutronMl2PluginBase was
used which is neutron-plugin-ml2.yaml. This patch
fixes this to use neutron-plugin-ml2-ovn.yaml which
correctly configures neutron for ovn metadata.

Change-Id: I7cadd0567951b85c1ba69d4b4843ee29b67e7a11
Closes-Bug: #1757134
(cherry picked from commit e534a7a213294bdf8908addaa3b3da4e070a78dc)

commit_message:
Follow the new PTI for document build

For compliance with the Project Testing Interface as described in:
[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html
[2] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-December/125710.html

Remove [build_sphinx] section:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128594.html

Change-Id: Ie39678188342b23d79ab9f806b1128a6163871ed

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Ie9af7f8458571e89a91bac8497c3cd8612fdcb35
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Amend the migration paging spec for uuid in server migrations response

During the review of I7e01f95d7173d9217f76e838b3ea71555151ef56
we made the decision to also add the migration uuid to the server
migrations GET responses to be consistent with the os-migrations
change to add the uuid to the response. This change simply amends
the spec to mention that change as well.

Part of blueprint add-pagination-and-change-since-for-migration-list

Change-Id: Icdd598d34748240a3ed9dade561f8f34857adbc3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/04/532904/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Also, since we are going to add the ``uuid`` field to the response for the ``os-migrations`` API, we will also take this opportunity to add the migration ``uuid`` to the response for the ``GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations/{migration_id}`` and ``GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations`` server migrations APIs.

commit_message:
Don't assume nodepool.[private|public]_ipv4

Several places assume nodepool.[private|public]_ipv4 are set, which
may not be true in ipv6 environments like limestone.  Rework several
of the setup and checks to not assume they are there.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/556784
Change-Id: I8cbe78bc127652229917d9e7f531a95f4b6fb0f7

subject: Remove ETCD_DOWNLOAD_URL setting for devstack
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-28 01:22:59.000000000', 'files': ['devstack-vm-gate.sh', '.zuul.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate/commit/0d2481f31459d6e3efc2a73f5b5ca6c4473d93d3', 'message': "Remove ETCD_DOWNLOAD_URL setting for devstack

With devstack change I86104824a29d973a6288df1f24b7891feb86267c we have
started caching the etcd .tar.gz on nodes during daily builds.  Thus
currently this flag doesn't really do anything, because we source the
file from the local cache directory.

Only in the cache-miss fallback case does devstack try to download.
Really the only reason this happens is because we're trying to use a
new version, and since that won't be on tarballs.o.o without
intervention it makes thing unnecessarily complicated.  Thus remove
this set.

Change-Id: I8fab8efdb0259a34047e19bec965d3c694de5092
"}]
commit_message:
Remove ETCD_DOWNLOAD_URL setting for devstack

With devstack change I86104824a29d973a6288df1f24b7891feb86267c we have
started caching the etcd .tar.gz on nodes during daily builds.  Thus
currently this flag doesn't really do anything, because we source the
file from the local cache directory.

Only in the cache-miss fallback case does devstack try to download.
Really the only reason this happens is because we're trying to use a
new version, and since that won't be on tarballs.o.o without
intervention it makes thing unnecessarily complicated.  Thus remove
this set.

Change-Id: I8fab8efdb0259a34047e19bec965d3c694de5092

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I0477df2f4275b79380a8a277de38f97884938e3c
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Remove option standalone_network_plugin_ip_version

'standalone_network_plugin_ip_version' option has been
deprecated. This option has been replaced by
'network_plugin_ipv4_enabled' and
'network_plugin_ipv6_enabled' options.

Change-Id: I0251fecddac74578698bcda5d46e44ca16bd8a76
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/62/522462/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: 'standalone_network_plugin_ip_version', default=4, help="IP version of network. Optional." "Allowed values are '4' and '6'. Default value is '4'. " "Note: This option is no longer used and has no effect", deprecated_for_removal=True, deprecated_reason="This option has been replaced by " "'network_plugin_ipv4_enabled' and " "'network_plugin_ipv6_enabled' options."), cfg.IntOpt( if not (ipv4_enabled or ipv6_enabled): ip_version = int( self.configuration.standalone_network_plugin_ip_version) LOG.warning("You're using a deprecated option that may" " be removed and silently ignored in the future. " "Please use 'network_plugin_ipv4_enabled' or " "'network_plugin_ipv6_enabled' instead of " "'standalone_network_plugin_ip_version'.")

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: I8596b2a4d38c43cfa18e4dfa0c15990326ecc75c
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Augment object-expirer's StatsD buckets.

This commit adds three new StatsD buckets to the object expirer:

* object-expirer.deferred: times that the object DELETE attempt gets a
  404 or 412 and the expirer decides to retry the deletion later.

* object-expirer.bad_status: times that an unexpected status code was
  received from an object deletion attempt. Currently, this is
  everything except 2xx, 404, 409, and 412.

* object-expirer.dequeue: deletions of rows from the expirer queue,
  i.e. the containers in the ".expiring_objects" account.

Hopefully, this will give operators more visibility into what the
object expirer is doing.

Change-Id: I470c721c56c15817316d1042398227694f3f2aa0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/16/538016/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================== ==================================================== Metric Name Description -------------------------- ---------------------------------------------------- `object-expirer.objects` Count of objects expired. `object-expirer.deferred` Count of expiration attempts that failed but will be retried later. `object-expirer.dequeue` Count of entries removed from the expirer's queue. `object-expirer.errors` Count of errors encountered while attempting to expire an object. `object-expirer.bad_status` Count of unexpected status codes received while attempting to expire an object. `object-expirer.timing` Timing data for each object expiration attempt, including ones resulting in an error. ========================== ====================================================

commit_message:
Expose vlan trunking in metadata/configdrive

This proposal aims to expose vlan subinterfaces associatecd with trunk
ports in metadata and configdrive, with which cloud-init (or possibly
glean) can configure the vlan subinterfaces in the guest instances.

Change-Id: I23b4e98e8cdd380f52d18855b9a9d5163756b728
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/15/471815/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================================ Expose vlan trunking in metadata and configdrive ================================================ Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/example This proposal aims to expose vlan subinterfaces associatecd with trunk ports in metadata and configdrive, with which cloud-init (or possibly glean) can configure the vlan subinterfaces in the guest instances. Problem description =================== Vlan trunking has been supported since Mitaka (Refer to [1]_ and [2]_). With the current metadata/configdrive support in nova, however, vlan subinterfaces associated with trunk ports are not exposed to the guest instances. After an instance is booted up, one needs to use other means to configure vlan subinterfaces in the instance. In some use cases (e.g. NFV), automatic configuration of vlan subinterfaces through cloud-init is not required or needed. Use Cases --------- A user would like to see a nova instance with trunk ports booted up with the trunks and their associated subinterfaces properly configured and brought up. It's particularly useful with Baremetal instances. For example, a baremetal server with a single physical port may be connected to multiple vlan networks. Once the BM server is booted up with Ironic, its networking interfaces can be automatically configured and brought up. It's possible that some users (such as some NFV use cases) wouldn't like to expose the vlan subinterfaces in the network metadata/configdrive. A configuration knob is desirable to turn on/off this feature. Proposed change =============== vlan subinterfaces are supported in network_data.json file (Refer to [3]_). The proposal is to populate the network_data.json file with the vlan subinterfaces associated with neutron trunk ports. Currently, only the trunk port itself is added into the network_info cache as part of an instance's info_cache. This needs to be changed in order to support vlan subinterfaces configuration. Trunk subport information is available in the trunk_details dictionary in a trunk port. Neutron ports corresponding to the trunk subports in trunk_details will be retrieved, new type of VIFs will be created after them and added into the network_info cache. Note that these trunk subport VIFs will not be exposed in the instance's domail XML as networking interfaces. To do that, a special VIF type 'trunk_subport' is used for these VIF objects, whose plug/unplug methods will be no-op. A couple of new fields will be added in the VIF object as meta fields. * subport_ids: this field is available for a trunk_port VIF * segmentation_id: this filed is available for a sub port VIF An example network_data.json file for an instance booted with one trunk port that has two subports may look like in below: .. code-block:: json { services": [], "networks": [ { "network_id": "9f1c0636-ba1f-42fd-a741-a2d0194704b5", "link": "tapad7e2436-35", "type": "ipv4_dhcp", "id": "network0" }, { "network_id": "ea077fad-e52a-4fa1-952f-06110e436d7d", "link": "tap143d8632-e3", "type": "ipv4_dhcp", "id": "network1" }, { "network_id": "bbd6f034-a600-46c1-b22f-0502697e179e", "link": "tap4bc16b9c-e2", "type": "ipv4_dhcp", "id": "network2" }, ], "links": [ { // trunk "ethernet_mac_address": "fa:16:3e:54:2e:51", "mtu": 1500, "type": "ovs", "id": "tapad7e2436-35", "vif_id": "ad7e2436-3583-4ae3-844b-06e6b0adaf04" }, { // sub interface "vif_id": "143d8632-e320-4fdb-aa07-bf2767085efd", "mtu": 1500, "vlan_link": "tapad7e2436-35", "vlan_id": 3279, "type": "vlan", "id": "tap143d8632-e3", "vlan_mac_address": "fa:16:3e:8e:b4:99" }, { // sub interface "vif_id": "4bc16b9c-e2b6-4c09-ba98-e94160cce12d", "mtu": 1500, "vlan_link":"tapad7e2436-35", "vlan_id": 3274, "type": "vlan", "id": "tap4bc16b9c-e2", "vlan_mac_address": "fa:16:3e:a4:93:98" }, ] } A config option inject_trunk_details will be added. If it's true, vlan subinterfaces associated with trunk ports will be exposed in the metadata/configdrive. Its default value is False. Alternatives ------------ It's possible to retrieve trunk subport information at the time of generating the network metadata, without adding them in the network_info cache. Some disadvantages: * new network API methods are required to retrieve neutron ports, and called at the time of generating the network metadata. * increased number of API calls to neutron due to retrieving neutron ports. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- With the proposed change, 'nova list' will be able to see not only the trunk ports but also the associated subports. If this is not desirable, it can be changed not to do so. Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- A new config option inject_trunk_details is added. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Baodong Li Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Retrieve trunk subports and create VIFs in neutronv2 * Disregard trunk subport VIFs in libvirt domain XML * Populate network_data.json with trunk subports Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Do we need tempest tests to check subport connectivity? Documentation Impact ==================== The VLAN trunk doc needs to be updated with the new config option inject_trunk_details. References ========== .. [1] `Neutron/TrunkPort <https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Neutron/TrunkPort>`_. .. [2] `VLAN trunking networks for NFV <https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/ neutron-specs/specs/kilo/nfv-vlan-trunks.html>`_. .. [3] `API: Proxy neutron configuration to guest instance <https://specs. openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/liberty/implemented/metadata- service-network-info.html>`_. History ======= N/A

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-27 19:00:00.000000000', 'files': ['openstack_releases/cmds/validate.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/releases/commit/0dd96d7e462d98e7377e9b195e016315de4a3637', 'message': 'look at correct branch when determining the sdist name

commit_message:
look at correct branch when determining the sdist name

We need to check out each repository to the hash for the latest
release on the branch to check the sdist name because (a) the name may
change over time and (b) the setup.py file may be removed from master
after a project is retired.

Change-Id: Id207d2ee7e2b70ffad562c7912a0543a4b9f9750
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/14/557014/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @applies_to_released # Check out the repositories to the hash for the latest release on # the branch so we can find the setup.py there (if it exists), in # case that has been removed from master after a project is # retired. This also ensures we get the right name for the branch, # in case the sdist name changes over time. latest_release = deliv.releases[-1] for project in latest_release.projects: gitutils.safe_clone_repo( context.workdir, project.repo.name, project.hash, context)

subject: Fix health manager edge case with zombie amphora
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-27 13:43:39.000000000', 'files': ['octavia/tests/unit/controller/worker/test_controller_worker.py', 'octavia/controller/worker/controller_worker.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/e06b95f6676959a694fdbce2293dd747fcf23730', 'message': 'Fix health manager edge case with zombie amphora

There is a edge case where amphora may have been deleted, marked deleted in
our database, but still be running in nova. One example is an instance stuck
in nova "deleting" status. These can still report health heartbeats, but
we will see them as failed as they are reporting load balancing configuration
that we do not have a record for. This will lead to a failover to repair the
amphora, which will re-attempt the delete and reset the amphora health record.
Which can lead to another failover attempt.

This patch will log and leave the amphora as "busy" if a failover is attempted
on an amphora we show as "DELETED". This will prevent repeated failover
attempts on "DELETED" amphora that are still alive in the compute system.

It also fixes a mis-named mock object in a failover test.

Change-Id: I3397ffacf8e08964ecd4b47f2353542b6bc57645
(cherry picked from commit 1a35d6dc81b96b34f1b5251540afcbe62f2fb0d2)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix health manager edge case with zombie amphora

There is a edge case where amphora may have been deleted, marked deleted in
our database, but still be running in nova. One example is an instance stuck
in nova "deleting" status. These can still report health heartbeats, but
we will see them as failed as they are reporting load balancing configuration
that we do not have a record for. This will lead to a failover to repair the
amphora, which will re-attempt the delete and reset the amphora health record.
Which can lead to another failover attempt.

This patch will log and leave the amphora as "busy" if a failover is attempted
on an amphora we show as "DELETED". This will prevent repeated failover
attempts on "DELETED" amphora that are still alive in the compute system.

It also fixes a mis-named mock object in a failover test.

Change-Id: I3397ffacf8e08964ecd4b47f2353542b6bc57645
(cherry picked from commit 1a35d6dc81b96b34f1b5251540afcbe62f2fb0d2)

commit_message:
more robustly handle error when we can't determine sdist name

Instead of passing None to the service as the sdist name, report that
situation as an error.

Change-Id: Ib6380d997db780ae324a4df61fdfa7f17e4507c3
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/13/557013/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: return if not pypi_name: context.error( 'Could not determine a valid PyPI dist name for {}'.format( deliv.name)) return

commit_message:
api-ref: Parameter verification for servers.inc (1/3)

This patch verifies query parameters.
Subsequent patches will verify other parameters.

Change-Id: I6078c0c8ebc888dc120f446f228a3b0433b89a76
Partial-Bug: #1738930

commit_message:
Fix parameter error in image_utils

Ref patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/514658/

1. Fix parameter error of method fetch_to_volume_format that
   called in fetch_to_raw and fetch_to_vhd.
2. Add new parameter volume_subformat for fetch_to_vhd to keep
   the same business with [Ref patch].

Change-Id: Id30ffd8a40eca841b5d6461c2f0269a0d9a4d628

subject: Process conntrack updates in worker threads
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-02-17 18:30:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/98df75eb7137070d398bc7473acdabdd09f57da9', 'message': 'Process conntrack updates in worker threads

With a large number of instances and/or security group rules,
conntrack updates when ports are removed or rules are changed
can take a long time to process.  By enqueuing these to a set
or worker threads, the agent can continue with other work while
they are processed in the background.

This is a change in behavior in the agent since it could
program a new set of security group rules before all existing
conntrack entries are deleted, but since the iptables or OVSfw
NAT rules will have been removed, it should not pose a
security issue.

Change-Id: Ibf858c7fdf7a822a30e4a0c4722d70fd272741b6
Closes-bug: #1745468
(cherry picked from commit 65a81623fc0377b26d2d5800607f7c3acc08c45a)
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-03-18 18:45:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/b48f598819b41fb7414df1edb3a60fafdc620066', 'message': 'Process conntrack updates in worker threads

With a large number of instances and/or security group rules,
conntrack updates when ports are removed or rules are changed
can take a long time to process.  By enqueuing these to a set
or worker threads, the agent can continue with other work while
they are processed in the background.

This is a change in behavior in the agent since it could
program a new set of security group rules before all existing
conntrack entries are deleted, but since the iptables or OVSfw
NAT rules will have been removed, it should not pose a
security issue.

Change-Id: Ibf858c7fdf7a822a30e4a0c4722d70fd272741b6
Closes-bug: #1745468
(cherry picked from commit 65a81623fc0377b26d2d5800607f7c3acc08c45a)

commit_message:
Process conntrack updates in worker threads

With a large number of instances and/or security group rules,
conntrack updates when ports are removed or rules are changed
can take a long time to process.  By enqueuing these to a set
or worker threads, the agent can continue with other work while
they are processed in the background.

This is a change in behavior in the agent since it could
program a new set of security group rules before all existing
conntrack entries are deleted, but since the iptables or OVSfw
NAT rules will have been removed, it should not pose a
security issue.

Change-Id: Ibf858c7fdf7a822a30e4a0c4722d70fd272741b6
Closes-bug: #1745468
(cherry picked from commit 65a81623fc0377b26d2d5800607f7c3acc08c45a)

added_lines: import eventletfrom six.moves import queue as Queueclass IpConntrackUpdate(object): """Encapsulates a conntrack update An instance of this object carries the information necessary to process a request to update the conntrack table. """ def __init__(self, device_info_list, rule, remote_ips): self.device_info_list = device_info_list self.rule = rule self.remote_ips = remote_ips class IpConntrackProcessingQueue(object): """Manager of the queue of conntrack updates to process.""" def __init__(self): self._queue = Queue.Queue() def add(self, update): self._queue.put(update) def updates(self): """Grabs the next conntrack update from the queue and processes.""" while not self._queue.empty(): update = self._queue.get() yield update self._queue = IpConntrackProcessingQueue() self.start_process_queue() def start_process_queue(self): eventlet.spawn_n(self._process_queue_loop) def _process_queue_loop(self): LOG.debug("Starting ipconntrack _process_queue_loop()") pool = eventlet.GreenPool(size=8) while True: pool.spawn_n(self._process_queue) def _process_queue(self): for update in self._queue.updates(): if update.remote_ips: for remote_ip in update.remote_ips: self._delete_conntrack_state( update.device_info_list, update.rule, remote_ip) else: self._delete_conntrack_state(update.device_info_list, update.rule) def _process(self, device_info_list, rule, remote_ips=None): # queue the update to allow the caller to resume its work update = IpConntrackUpdate(device_info_list, rule, remote_ips) self._queue.add(update) self._process(device_info_list, rule) self._process(device_info_list, rule, remote_ips)
deleted_lines: self._delete_conntrack_state(device_info_list, rule) if remote_ips: for remote_ip in remote_ips: self._delete_conntrack_state( device_info_list, rule, remote_ip) else: self._delete_conntrack_state(device_info_list, rule)

commit_message:
Fix post up checksum script

The post up checksum script was being executed by the legacy networking
To ensure we retain the same capabilities the checksum fix script has
been moved into a systemd oneshot service.

Change-Id: I58d393eb8c78a541142a29c5e0678cbd6ec18b65
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

added_lines: # NOTE: Remove this in S # This option has been removed with the implementation of networkd within the # host and container. Additionally the execution of this script is now # controlled by a systemd oneshot service so the legacy configs are no longer # needed.

commit_message:
remove zmq tests

At the Rocky PTG the Oslo team decided to once again deprecate and
remove the ZMQ driver. This is the first part of doing that, which
removes the unit tests and extra functional test jobs, which are
failing.

Change-Id: Ia02adf122d2d4ff281e7c9fd3dff8894da241925
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Remove required-projects from job definition

Given that the parent is the functional job, which already
includes all the required roles, this is unnecessary and
only serves to slow down the test.

Change-Id: Iadcebc9eca9e279ea647a7a35bff5d00f82489f1

commit_message:
Fix fluentd upgrade tasks during FFU.

The upgrade task doesn't check for the service existence which make
the upgrade fails during ffu.

We're using the set_facts idiom as it persist between steps.

Closes-Bug: #1757985

Change-Id: I1d3ccd7d3fb641d187f214c20f1d6a4d6113304a

commit_message:
Set trusted port only once in iptables firewall driver

Patch [1] added configuration of forward rule for trusted ports in
iptables firewall driver.

This patch fixes issue with many "duplicate iptables rule detected"
warning messages due to try to add such forward rule each time when
trusted port is updated.
Now such rule is added only once for port.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/525607/

Change-Id: Ib816887f07f16b6ac865bb81d0f27f12d0b47dfb
Closes-Bug: #1754770
(cherry picked from commit 8be0c2a551fea0c02d757c6ad460f8435423ec32)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/59/556659/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _test_process_trusted_ports(self, configured): port = self._fake_port() port['id'] = 'tapfake_dev' calls = [ mock.call.add_chain('sg-fallback'), mock.call.add_rule('sg-fallback', '-j DROP', comment=ic.UNMATCH_DROP)] if configured: self.firewall.trusted_ports.append(port['id']) else: calls.append( mock.call.add_rule('FORWARD', '-m physdev --physdev-out tapfake_dev ' '--physdev-is-bridged ' '-j ACCEPT', comment=ic.TRUSTED_ACCEPT)) filter_inst = self.v4filter_inst self.firewall.process_trusted_ports([port['id']]) comb = zip(calls, filter_inst.mock_calls) for (l, r) in comb: self.assertEqual(l, r) filter_inst.assert_has_calls(calls) self.assertIn(port['id'], self.firewall.trusted_ports) def test_process_trusted_ports(self): self._test_process_trusted_ports(False) def test_process_trusted_ports_already_configured(self): self._test_process_trusted_ports(True) def _test_remove_trusted_ports(self, configured): port = self._fake_port() port['id'] = 'tapfake_dev' calls = [ mock.call.add_chain('sg-fallback'), mock.call.add_rule('sg-fallback', '-j DROP', comment=ic.UNMATCH_DROP)] if configured: self.firewall.trusted_ports.append(port['id']) calls.append( mock.call.remove_rule('FORWARD', '-m physdev --physdev-out tapfake_dev ' '--physdev-is-bridged -j ACCEPT')) filter_inst = self.v4filter_inst self.firewall.remove_trusted_ports([port['id']]) comb = zip(calls, filter_inst.mock_calls) for (l, r) in comb: self.assertEqual(l, r) filter_inst.assert_has_calls(calls) self.assertNotIn(port['id'], self.firewall.trusted_ports) def test_remove_trusted_ports(self): self._test_remove_trusted_ports(True) def test_process_remove_ports_not_configured(self): self._test_remove_trusted_ports(False)

commit_message:
Amend volume multi-attach spec

* The minimum required Cinder API microversion that Nova
  checks for is 3.44.
* The first TODO about disallowing a volume to be attached to
  the same instance multiple times has been resolved by
  change I049f00f993e45eeb090a1e1a5e5696cf2f103187.
* The second TODO about adding a new microversion is removed;
  we added microversion 2.60 for multiattach volume support in nova.

Change-Id: I12efa58b95ba1a2f8615256924f4a7a44c354ced
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/52/544152/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: attach/detach API which is available from the API microversion 3.44 [#]_.A new compute API microversion will be added since users will need some way to discover if they can perform volume multiattach. The semantics of the microversion will be similar to the `2.49`_ microversion for tagged attach. .. _2.49: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html#id44.. [#] https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/contributor/api_microversion_history.html#id41
deleted_lines: attach/detach API which is available from the API microversion 3.45 [#]_... todo:: A volume should only be allowed to be attached to a given instance once, regardless of multiattach. This requires investigation since the ``nova.block_device_mappings`` table and ``cinder.volume_attachment`` tables do not have unique constraints on volume_id and instance_uuid. .. todo:: Whether or not a new compute API microversion is needed will be determined during implementation and code review. API users will need some way to discover if they can perform volume multiattach and a microversion might be the signal, but it is unclear if Nova would block those requests on a lower microversion, e.g. 2.1. It probably makes sense to do a microversion like 2.49 for tagged attach capabilities... [#] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/509005/

commit_message:
Dell EMC SC: Find volume folder API call fails on root folders

Changes to the SC API have changed how calls are made to the
StorageCenter/ScVolumeFolder/GetList payload filter options. In
the case of a folder under root this call could fail depending on
the API.

Change-Id: I2ab2160478d2163dbb45175aa5f1b884f316db24
(cherry picked from commit c9a7fb8da533251772b79140c7161b393c52f15b)

commit_message:
tests: don't rely on configuration files outside tests directory

Following the similar Neutron change. [1]

Recently, the way sibling projects are installed were changed.
It broke networking-midonet gate as neutron-fwaas was installed
under site-packages, where the etc directory is not available.

[1] If1f5ebd981cf06558d5102524211799676068889

Closes-Bug: #1758062
Change-Id: I72aeeac8cbe07f6fc6cb4acf54fb632587d890a0

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Idd1779c38f0fcd49130971d4eb2679247af796ce
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Migrate neutron-vpnaas API definitions to neutron-lib

Neutron-vpnaas is intending to bring back into the stadium.
So, neutron-vpnaas must migrate it's API definition to neutron-lib.

Co-Authored-By: Anh Tran <trananhkma@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Hunt Xu <mhuntxu@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I06760fbbbc87570412a21364fba58efe880a907b

commit_message:
Use wait_random_exponential from tenacity 4.4.0

Now that we depend on tenacity >=4.4.0, we can use the library's version of
the wait_random_exponential wait strategy in place of our own.

Change-Id: I13d3222808a98ef7e333f58df931c8f950ac1221
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/556309
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/40/556540/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: class wait_random_exponential(tenacity.wait_exponential): """Random wait strategy with a geometrically increasing amount of jitter. Implements the truncated binary exponential backoff algorithm as used in e.g. CSMA media access control. The retry occurs at a random time in a (geometrically) expanding interval constrained by minimum and maximum limits. """ def __init__(self, min=0, multiplier=1, max=tenacity._utils.MAX_WAIT, exp_base=2): super(wait_random_exponential, self).__init__(multiplier=multiplier, max=(max-min), exp_base=exp_base) self._random = tenacity.wait_random(min=min, max=(min + multiplier)) def __call__(self, previous_attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt): jitter = super(wait_random_exponential, self).__call__(previous_attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt) self._random.wait_random_max = self._random.wait_random_min + jitter return self._random(previous_attempt_number, delay_since_first_attempt) wait_strategy = wait_random_exponential(max=60)

commit_message:
Re-enable Limestone at 10 nodes with custom labels

This will allow us to troubleshoot issues we've noticed with Limestone.
Using custom labels means normal jobs won't be impacted.

Change-Id: I28748caf5ee8d059a25d9c38429e0ad57c99b8b5

subject: tasks: Ensure Open vSwitch is started for all providers that need it
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-27 15:46:29.000000000', 'files': ['vars/main.yml', 'tasks/neutron_install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron/commit/360c9f9e60a3930028fe58866c2a90f36fa1979b', 'message': 'tasks: Ensure Open vSwitch is started for all providers that need it

Previously, openvswitch was only started when we were using the ODL
provider but we should start it for all providers that need it. As such
we move the conditional which checks whether Open vSwitch is needed into
a new variable and we use that to start/enable the service and also to

commit_message:
tasks: Ensure Open vSwitch is started for all providers that need it

Previously, openvswitch was only started when we were using the ODL
provider but we should start it for all providers that need it. As such
we move the conditional which checks whether Open vSwitch is needed into
a new variable and we use that to start/enable the service and also to
install the package when needed.

Change-Id: I4ec4fc2c2124a941f24478cbdf39ed34c0dce56f
(cherry picked from commit 4b940c8337017dcfb275f3eba90f4e8f5fa6dffc)

commit_message:
bump fs20 tempest to 3 workers

Tempest is timing out in the tripleo promotion jobs.
Let's see if bumping the workers from 2 to 3 speeds
it up enough and if it stays reliable.

Change-Id: I37433a0297874a19b33e7b425e1bb2716e7e176b

commit_message:
Don't restart ivs/nfvswitch in os-net-config

Restarting ivs during ugrades causes network disruptions. Removing both
the ivs and nvfswitch restarts as they are not required.

Change-Id: I3d26cbc8484c72d6bfc133c59c8fc065add226c9
Closes-Bug: 1757130

commit_message:
Remove /etc/os-net-config/config.json in os-apply-config

In the new style of nic config files, os-net-config is invoked by
the script run-os-net-config.sh, not by os-apply-config.  This is the
only format supported in Queens. Remove the os-apply-config version
of /etc/os-net-config/config.json to prevent os-apply-config from
attempting to run with an empty config.json file.

Note that /etc/os-net-config/config.json no longer exists in
tripleo-image-elements.

Change-Id: Ica86382c4e5a1463ed8b2146e3ec490b7e2c9452
Closes-Bug: 1758161

commit_message:
Zuul: Remove project name

Zuul no longer requires the project-name for in-repo configuration.
Omitting it makes forking or renaming projects easier.

commit_message:
add lower-constraints job

Create a tox environment for running the unit tests against the lower
bounds of the dependencies.

Create a lower-constraints.txt to be used to enforce the lower bounds
in those tests.

Add openstack-tox-lower-constraints job to the zuul configuration.

See http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-March/128352.html
for more details.

Change-Id: Iec6e055c97a440ac62ea684fe0130a4f53ed27bb
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/555034
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/553063
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Avoid tox-install.sh

Instead of using tox-install.sh, we can install horizon and neutron
now directly from pypi - or use the current branch in CI system using
tox-siblings.

Update tox.ini for this change and add neutron to requirements file.

Change-Id: Ib7d66460c21e3dbcf2d55d7ecac23315daa65ec7

commit_message:
Share overcloud Heat templates for undercloud conf

Now that we have --use-heat mode by default, allow
to alter the default location of tripleo heat templates for
undercloud as well.

Move related cleanup and output dir to the expected DEFAULT
namespace.

Related-bug: #1749683
Change-Id: I050c09c4447fa45dd6e82dc3199bec60b1a10696
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix routings headers

The current implementation that remaps the headers of jobs objects
fails in python3. This change simplify the implementation and fixes
the current failures.

Change-Id: I6620a8aeff2b678ab07ae9a55ef2f1e481bdef5d
(cherry picked from commit 8f21b50e4ce3b20a8ecabc97947634a55d8c497e)

commit_message:
Create migration context for live-migration

Since a5b920a external instance event routing is
done by checking migration_context for instance.
The problem here is that claims aren't used for
live-migration yet, and no migration_context is created.

This patch fixes this problem by explicitly creating
migration_context on conductor's side, to ensure routing will
work properly.

While this change is a hotfix the rationale for doing that it's
backportable nature.

Change-Id: Id4d3e856c33d16fe80af46aa3c3f6edb77ab2269
Related-Bug: #1414559
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/55/413555/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(tdurakov): migration context is not created for live-migration # on resource tracker for computes prior to ocata. To fix external # events routing issue during upgrades migration_context should be # explicitly created on conductor's side. # See bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1624052 mig_context = objects.MigrationContext( context=context, instance_uuid=instance.uuid, migration_id=migration.id, old_numa_topology=instance.numa_topology, new_numa_topology=instance.numa_topology, old_pci_devices=instance.pci_devices, new_pci_devices=instance.pci_devices, old_pci_requests=instance.pci_requests, new_pci_requests=instance.pci_requests) instance.migration_context = mig_context instance.save()

commit_message:
Allow stacks to remove old update resources

Change I6c5eafe76eb53bc38d100a9ba132dd8fe6dd2d5f removed old
update-related resources, but it seems that we need to do such removal
in two steps to allow smooth transition for existing stacks: first
remove them from the stack, and only then completely remove the
mapping from resource registry. If we try to do both at the same time,
we get:

ERROR: The Resource Type (OS::TripleO::Tasks::UpdateWorkflow) could
not be found.

So we'll need to keep these resource registry entries around (even
though mapped to OS::Heat::None) for the Rocky cycle still. They can
be removed in S.

Change-Id: I866e659bd373dfb2816508165b7f3abb9580e2d0
Closes-Bug: #1758014
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/50/555250/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Enable the compute node's UUID to be overridden when a provider config

Change-Id: Ice67f962a582276f2026bfbf96e3bf430643ff64
blueprint: override-compute-node-uuid
"}]
commit_message:
Allow overriding a compute node's UUID

Enable the compute node's UUID to be overridden when a provider config
YAML file is present on the compute host.

Change-Id: Ice67f962a582276f2026bfbf96e3bf430643ff64
blueprint: override-compute-node-uuid
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/15/551315/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================== Override compute node UUID ========================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/override-compute-node-uuid This is a proposal to allow the resource tracker on the ``nova-compute`` service worker to override the UUID and name for the compute node record it creates in the ``compute_nodes`` table in the nova cell database and the corresponding resource provider record it creates in the placement API. Problem description =================== Imagine the ``nova-compute`` and Neutron ML2 agent managing the port resources on a piece of hardware are deployed in separate containers (or VMs) on a baremetal host computer. We would like both the virt driver in the ``nova-compute`` as well as the Neutron agent to use the `update_provider_tree`_ interface for tracking inventory and trait information for the resource providers that each is responsible for. .. _update_provider_tree: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/540111/ Imagine that the Neutron agent wants to inform the placement API about inventory of ``SRIOV_NET_VF`` resources and a set of NIC capabilities on four SR-IOV physical functions on the host hardware. Using the ``update_provider_tree`` interface, the Neutron agent would retrieve a `ProviderTree`_ object representing the tree of resource providers with a root provider of the compute node. The Neutron agent would then proceed to call ``ProviderTree.new_child()`` to add resource provider records for the four SR-IOV physical functions. For each of these physical functions, the Neutron agent would then add inventory records for the ``SRIOV_NET_VF`` resources and apply traits to the resource providers that represent the NIC capabilities for the physical functions. .. _ProviderTree: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/queens/nova/compute/provider_tree.py Currently, however, there is a chicken-and-egg problem that exists for the Neutron agent. Consider the case when both the ``nova-compute`` and the Neutron agent start for the first time. There is no ``compute_nodes`` record in the cell database. There is no resource provider record created for the compute node in the placement API. When starting up, the ``nova-compute`` service will ask the virt driver for the inventory and capabilities of the host and, upon noticing there is no compute node in the cell DB and resource provider record in the placement API, the resource tracker will create them. Importantly, the resource tracker `creates`_ the compute node by `passing in`_ the value of the nova.conf ``CONF.host`` configuration option. Once the ``compute_nodes`` record has been written via the ``nova.objects.ComputeNode.create()`` object method, the compute node will have a UUID value. The resource tracker, via the scheduler reportclient, will `use that UUID`_ when creating the resource provider record in the placement API. This is problematic for the Neutron agent in a couple ways. First, the Neutron agent doesn't know what the UUID of the compute node resource provider is. It needs to know this information in order to get the ``ProviderTree`` it will use to add the SR-IOV physical function child providers to. Secondly, the Neutron agent doesn't have any way to look up the compute node's resource provider record by the provider name *either*, since the Neutron agent is running in a separate container and it could not rely on its own value of ``CONF.host`` being the same as the value for the ``nova-compute`` container. Therefore, the Neutron agent doesn't have a way of getting the ``ProviderTree`` rooted with the resource provider representing the compute node it is responsible for. .. _creates: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/queens/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L580-L584 .. _passing in: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/queens/nova/manager.py#L96 .. _use that UUID: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/queens/nova/compute/resource_tracker.py#L876 Use Cases --------- A Cyborg, Neutron ML2 or DHCP agent wants to create child resource providers under the parent compute node resource provider record and must be able to identify the compute node even if the ``nova-compute`` service worker has yet to create a resource provider record for the compute node in the placement API (or even before adding a record to the cell DB's ``compute_nodes`` table) An operator wishes to pre-create a batch of resource provider and inventory records in the placement API so that they can set allocation ratios and traits against those resource providers in batches. They want to be able to do this before any ``nova-compute`` service workers even start. Proposed change =============== Changes to ``nova-compute`` --------------------------- The ``nova-compute`` resource tracker's constructor will look for a provider descriptor file at the location indicated by a new ``CONF.compute.provider_descriptor_path`` configuration option. If this CONF option is None, the resource tracker's current behaviour will not change. If set to some value, this value will be passed to the ``os_placement.provider.config.from_file()`` method which will return an ``os_placement.provider.config.ProviderConfig`` object representing the override information for the compute node. .. note:: The ``CONF.compute.provider_descriptor_path`` CONF option only makes sense for ``nova-compute`` service workers that are running a virt driver that controls a **single** compute node. For virt drivers that manage multiple compute nodes, like Ironic and PowerVM, alternate methods of overriding compute node UUIDs for multiple compute nodes will need to be considered. Code will be added to the ``nova-compute`` resource tracker's ``_init_compute_node()`` method that will set the ``nova.objects.ComputeNode`` object's uuid field to the value of any override found in the ``os_placement.provider.config.ProviderConfig`` object. Changes other agents -------------------- While this spec doesn't propose specific changes to other agents, we will note that other agents will be able to load provider config YAML files in the same fashion as the resource tracker in the ``nova-compute`` services. These other agents may then poll the placement API for a specific resource provider by UUID, sleeping some amount of time when getting a ``404 Not Found`` until the ``nova-compute`` starts up and ends up creating the resource provider in the placement service. At this point, the other agent may begin adding traits and inventory to child providers of the root compute node resource provider. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- ``nova.objects.ComputeNode`` will need to be modified so that the ``uuid`` field can be set. This will require removing the readonly attribute of the field and removing any code that prohibits the setting of the ``uuid`` field manually. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- Deployers wishing to pre-set UUIDs for their compute hosts will need to set the new ``CONF.provider_descriptor_path`` configuration option in their nova.conf files. Provider descriptor YAML files will need to be generated for each compute host. Developer impact ---------------- None Upgrade impact -------------- There should not be any upgrade impact. Existing compute hosts will already have their compute node's UUID set, obviously, so the new ``CONF.provider_descriptor_path`` option and behaviour will only affect compute hosts that have yet to be brought online. We may wish to log a warning if an existing compute host gets a non-None ``CONF.provider_descriptor_path`` value and overrides contained in the provider descriptor YAML file conflict with the existing compute node's UUID. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- jaypipes Work Items ---------- * Create the new CONF option along with documentation about its purpose * Modify the resource tracker to use the overrides present in any provider descriptor YAML file when first creating the ``compute_nodes`` object Dependencies ============ The `provider config file`_ blueprint is required for this spec. .. _provider config file: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/provider-config-file Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== Full documentation on the purpose and usage of the new configuration option. References ========== Some notes on the topic of how to we might override a compute node's UUID are available in the etherpad from the Rocky PTG: https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/nova-ptg-rocky-placement
